CERTIFIED RECEIPT REQUESTED

September 8, 2016

Jennifer Reba Edwards, Esq.
The Animal Law Center, LLC
6870 W. 52nd Ave., Ste. 203
Arvada, CO 80002

Subject; William Brackston Lee, II d/b/a Laughing Valley Rane spondent
Docket: 14-0021
Authority: Animal Welfare Act

Dear Ms. Edwards:

Enclosed is a copy of the Decision and Order issued in this proceeding by Administrative Law
Judge, Chief Judge McCartney on September 8, 2016. Please note that each party has thirty
(30) days after being served with a copy of this Decision and Order to file an appeal to the
Department’s Judicial Officer.

If no appeal is filed, the Decision and Order shall become final and effective as to each party
thirty-five (35) days after the date of service. However, if an appeal is filed the Decision and
Order is not final for purposes of judicial review. Upon completion of judicial review, an
Order will be issued by the Secretary of Agriculture or the Judicial Officer.

If you elect to file an appeal, please note that an original and three (3) copies of the appeal are
required. You may also elect to file by electronic service at

OALJHearingClerks@ocio.usda.gov, Please refer to the Uniform Rules of Practice (7 C.F.R. §

1,145) to obtain information regarding the procedure for filing an appeal. Lastly. you received
a copy of the Uniform Rules of Practice when you were served with the Complaint.

Sincerely,

(2 Leach-Carlos

Hearing Clerk

cc:

Colleen A. Carroll, OGC

CH: 9/8/16

August 10, 2016

Wildlife World Zoo, Inc.
16501 W. Northern Avenue
Litchfield Park, AZ 85340

Louis M. Ollson, Sr.
16501 W. Northern Avenue
Litchfield Park, AZ 85340

SETTLEMENT AGREEMENT

Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you violated the Animal Welfare Act (7 U.S.C. § 2131 et seq.)
(AWA), as described in the attached Settlement Agreement. Our agency, the
Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing
the AWA, and other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and
plant pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may impose civil
penalties of up to $10,000, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Settlement Agreement. We are offering you the opportunity to resolve this matter
by paying an amount that is much lower than the maximum civil penalty.

What are the terms of the Settlement Agreement?

You should review the information in this Settlement Agreement, including the
citation and notification of penalty.

If you agree to waive your right to a hearing and pay the penalty, then do the
following:

o Pay the amount due, $2,350, by September 12, 2016. You can
pay by check, money order, or credit card. For your convenience,
we have included additional instructions for making payments.

o If you are unable to pay the full amount due by September 12,
2016, you may be eligible for a payment plan. To request a
payment plan, you must use the enclosed form to submit a written
response to this letter by September 12, 2016, that indicates you
wish to pay the penalty and waive your right to a hearing. You
must also submit a copy of your most recent federal tax return. As
part of your response, please include a phone number and an email
address so that we may contact you.

Reference Number: AZ150085-
An Equal Opportunity Provider and Employer AC

Issuance Date: August 10. 2016
Version: Final



## Enforcement Records-AWA and HPA-Sept to Oct 2016_page_3
17-00922_000063

USDA
aeeil

What are my other options?

If you do not agree with the terms of this Settlement Agreement, submit a written
request for a hearing, with your Reference Number, to our office by September
12, 2016, at 4700 River Rd., Unit 85, Riverdale, MD, 20737.

What happens if I fail to respond?

If we do not receive a payment or hearing request from you by September 12,
2016, we will forward this matter to our Office of the General Counsel for
litigation.

What should I do if I need help?

If you have any questions concerning this letter, contact Kelly Ferrell at (301)
851-2755, or call our main office at (301) 851-2948.

Zama small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding APHIS’s
enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?

APHIS always welcomes comments on how it can better assist small
businesses. If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and
plant health laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small
Business Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you would prefer to comment to
someone outside APHIS, you may contact the Small Business Regulatory
Enforcement Ombudsperson at http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email
ombudsman@sba.gov, or toll free at 1-888-REG-FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s
office receives comments from small businesses and annually evaluates federal
agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs of
small businesses.

Sincerely,

Cf th ta

Steven M. Bennett, Acting Director
Investigative and Enforcement Services

Reference Number: AZ150085-
An Equal Opportunity Provider and Employer AC

Issuance Date: August 10. 2016
Version: Final



## Enforcement Records-AWA and HPA-Sept to Oct 2016_page_4
17-00922_000064

USDA
USDA

Wildlife World Zoo, Inc.
16501 W. Northern Avenue
Litchfield Park, AZ 85340

CITATION AND NOTIFICATION OF PENALTY

We believe that you violated the Animal Welfare Act (7 U.S.C. § 2131 et seq.)
(AWA), as described below.

Date of Violation: May 4, 2015

9 C.F.R. § 2.126(a)(4) Access and inspection of records and property;
submission of itineraries. Each dealer, exhibitor, intermediate handler, or
carrier, shall, during business hours, allow APHIS officials to inspect and
photograph the facilities, property and animals, as the APHIS officials consider
necessary to enforce the provisions of the Act, the regulations and the standards
in this subchapter.

You failed to inform APHIS officials of all of the areas containing
regulated animals so that APHIS could inspect them. APHIS asked
about specific areas, and your representative told APHIS that the
areas only contained the garbage dump, birds, and/or reptiles, and did
not disclose that they contained regulated animals until APHIS asked
to see those areas.

Date of Violation: May 4, 2015

9 C.F.R. § 3.80(a)(2)(ix) Primary enclosures. Primary enclosures for
nonhuman primates must meet the following minimum requirements: General
requirements. Primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that
they enable all surfaces in contact with nonhuman primates to be readily
cleaned and sanitized, or replaced when worn or soiled.

You failed to construct and maintain enclosures so that surfaces
could be readily cleaned or replaced when worn or soiled. The
enclosure housing two tamarins in the Tropics building had an area
approximately 5 inches long of exposed wood near the exhibit
window which could not be adequately cleaned or sanitized.

Date of Violation: May 4, 2015

9 C.F.R. § 3.129(b) Feeding. Food and receptacles, if used, shall be sufficient
in quantity and located so as to be accessible to all animals in the enclosure and
shall be placed so as to minimize contamination. Food receptacles shall be kept
clean and sanitary at all times. If self-feeders are used, adequate measures shall

Reference Number: AZ150085-
An Equal Opportunity Provider and Employer AC

Issuance Date: August 10. 2016
Version: Final



## Enforcement Records-AWA and HPA-Sept to Oct 2016_page_5
USDA
a

be taken to prevent molding, contamination, and deterioration or caking of
food.

You failed to feed animals in a way that would minimize
contamination. You were feeding the breeding goats on the ground,
and the feed had an accumulation of fecal matter in it.

Date of Violation: May 4, 2015

9 C.F.R. § 3.131(a) Sanitation. Cleaning of enclosures. Excreta shall be
removed from primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent
contamination of the animals contained therein and to minimize disease hazards
and to reduce odors. When enclosures are cleaned by hosing or flushing,
adequate measures shall be taken to protect the animals confined in such
enclosures from being directly sprayed with the stream of water or wetted
mvoluntarily.
You failed to remove excreta as often as necessary to prevent
contamination of the animals and minimize disease hazards. The
enclosure housing several goats had an excessive accumulation of
feces on the ground, such that the animals could not lie in their
enclosure without becoming contaminated by the waste material.

The penalty for the alleged violation(s) described above is $2,350.

Reference Number: AZ150085-
An Equal Opportunity Provider and Employer AC

Issuance Date: August 10, 2016
Version: Final

How To Pay The Penalty

You may pay your penalty immediately through secure online transactions or
phone using American Express, Discover, Diners Club, Master Card, and Visa, or
by U.S. Mail using a check, cashier’s check, or money order.

Online. Pay.gov allows you to make deferred and recurring credit card
payments through secure online payments. To submit your credit card
payment online:
1. Log on to https://www.pay.gov.
Click on Agency List.
Click on “A” in Index.
Click on Agriculture Department.
Click on Department of Agriculture.
Click on Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service —- APHIS
Customers (2nd listing).
7. Complete the required information and submit the form.
8. Enter payment information and submit your payment.
9. Print confirmation screen as your receipt.

Pi le BD

Phone. To make a credit card payment by phone:
1. Call (612) 336-3264 and speak to a Debt Management
Specialist.
2. State your Reference Number AZ150085-AC.
3. Submit your credit card information.

U.S. Mail. To make a payment by check, cashier’s check, or money
order:
1. Make the check, cashier’s check, or money order payable to the
Treasurer of the United States.
2. Write the Reference Number AZ150085-AC on your check,
cashier’s check, or money order.
3. Mail your payment to:
USDA — APHIS — GENERAL AZ150085-AC
P.O. Box 979043
St. Louis, MO 63197-9000

If You Are Unable To Pay In Full

Complete the attached form and return it to our office to request a payment plan.
Please be prepared to provide us with copies of your most recent federal tax return
so that we may determine whether you are eligible for a payment plan.

Reference Number: AZ150085-
An Equal Opportunity Provider and Employer AC

Issuance Date: August 10. 2016
Version: Final

SETTLEMENT AGREEMENT

Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you violated the Animal Welfare Act (7 U.S.C. § 2131 et seq.)
(AWA), as described in the attached Settlement Agreement. Our agency, the
Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing
the AWA, and other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and
plant pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may impose civil
penalties of up to $10,000, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Settlement Agreement. We are offering you the opportunity to resolve this matter
by paying an amount that is much lower than the maximum civil penalty.

What are the terms of the Settlement Agreement?

You should review the information in this Settlement Agreement, including the
citation and notification of penalty.

If you agree to waive your right to a hearing and pay the penalty, then do the
following:

o Pay the amount due, $22,850, by September 23, 2016. You can
pay by check, money order, or credit card. For your convenience,
we have included additional instructions for making payments.

o If you are unable to pay the full amount due by September 23,
2016, you may be eligible for a payment plan. To request a
payment plan, you must use the enclosed form to submit a written
response to this letter by September 23, 2016, that indicates you
wish to pay the penalty and waive your right to a hearing. You
must also submit a copy of your most recent federal tax return. As
part of your response, please include a phone number and an email
address so that we may contact you.

Reference Number: CA150065-
An Equal Opportunity Provider and Employer AC

Issuance Date: August 22, 2016
Version: Final

## Enforcement Records-AWA and HPA-Sept to Oct 2016_page_10
17-00922_000070

USDA
USDA

Los Angeles Zoo
5333 Zoo Drive
Los Angeles, CA 90027

CITATION AND NOTIFICATION OF PENALTY

We believe that you violated the Animal Welfare Act (7 U.S.C. § 2131 et seq.)
(AWA), as described below.

Date of Violation: April 29, 2014

9 C.F.R. § 2.40(b)(2) Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care
(dealers and exhibitors).

(b) Each dealer or exhibitor shall establish and maintain programs of adequate
veterinary care that include:

(2) The use of appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat
diseases and injuries, and the availability of emergency, weekend, and holiday
care

You failed to establish and maintain an adequate program of
veterinary care to include appropriate methods to prevent, control,
diagnose and treat diseases and injuries, and the availability of
emergency care. A female takin, “Qiji,” began showing signs of
labor during the afternoon and had a recent history of lethargy,
lameness, and swollen legs. A senior zookeeper contacted the
attending veterinarian that evening but could not reach him. The
zookeeper spoke with the attending veterinarian later that night and
the veterinarian stated that the issue would be dealt with in the
morning. You provided veterinary care to the takin the following
morning. The attending veterinarian euthanized the takin due to
findings discovered during a C-section to remove her fetus, which
had died. You subsequently found that the after-hours vet call list
was out of date.

Date of Violation: November 22, 2014

9 C.F.R. § 3.125(a) Facilities, general.

(a) Structural strength. The facility must be constructed of such material and of
such strength as appropriate for the animals involved. The indoor and outdoor
housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good
repair to protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals.

You failed to construct facilities of such material so as to contain the
animals. A female big horn sheep escaped her enclosure by jumping
a wall and a barrier fence. She then escaped the grounds by climbing

Reference Number: CA150065-
An Equal Opportunity Provider and Employer AC

Issuance Date: August 22, 2016
Version: Final



## Enforcement Records-AWA and HPA-Sept to Oct 2016_page_11
USDA
USDA

a stairway and jumping the perimeter fence. While outside she was
struck by an automobile and died shortly after being recaptured.

Date of Violation: July 2, 2015

9 C.F.R. § 3.75(a) Housing facilities, general.

(a) Structure: construction. Housing facilities for nonhuman primates must be
designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound for the species of
nonhuman primates housed in them. They must be kept in good repair, and they
must protect the animals from injury, contain the animals securely, and restrict
other animals from entering.

You failed to design and construct housing facilities for nonhuman
primates that protected them from injury, contained them securely,
and restricted other animals from entering. Two cotton top tamarins
went missing from their exhibit, which was an island-like peninsula
that had several access points, which would pennit entry of other
animals. You identified a surveillance video that showed a bobcat
walking away with one tamarin, and you also found the remains of
one tamarin. You did not find the second missing tamarin.

Date of Violation: March 3, 2016

9 C.F.R. § 3.127(d) Facilities, outdoor.

(d) Perimeter fence. On or after May 17, 2000, all outdoor housing facilities
(i.e., facilities not entirely indoors) must be enclosed by a perimeter fence that
is of sufficient height to keep animals and unauthorized persons out. Fences less
than 8 feet high for potentially dangerous animals, such as, but not limited to,
large felines (e.g., lions, tigers, leopards, cougars, etc.), bears, wolves,
rhinoceros, and elephants, or less than 6 feet high for other animals must be
approved in writing by the Administrator. The fence must be constructed so that
it protects the animals in the facility by restricting animals and unauthorized
persons from going through it or under it and having contact with the animals in
the facility, and so that it can function as a secondary containment system for
the animals in the facility. It must be of sufficient distance from the outside of
the primary enclosure to prevent physical contact between animals inside the
enclosure and animals or persons outside the perimeter fence. Such fences less
than 3 feet in distance from the primary enclosure must be approved in writing
by the Administrator.

You failed to construct a perimeter fence that protected the animals in
the facility by restricting animals and unauthorized persons from
going through it or under it and having contact with the animals in
the facility. A koala disappeared from her exhibit. The koalas
housed with her that night were unharmed. The design of this
enclosure allows several access points that could permit entry of
unauthorized animals. You found the remains of the missing koala
approximately 300 yards from the exhibit.

Reference Number: CA150065-
An Equal Opportunity Provider and Employer AC

Issuance Date: August 22, 2016
Version: Final

17-00922_000071


## Enforcement Records-AWA and HPA-Sept to Oct 2016_page_12
17-00922_000072

USDA
USDA

Date of Violation: March 10, 2016

9 C.F.R. § 3.127(d) Facilities, outdoor.

(d) Perimeter fence. On or after May 17, 2000, all outdoor housing facilities
(i.e., facilities not entirely indoors) must be enclosed by a perimeter fence that
is of sufficient height to keep animals and unauthorized persons out. Fences less
than 8 feet high for potentially dangerous animals, such as, but not limited to,
large felines (e.g., lions, tigers, leopards, cougars, etc.), bears, wolves,
rhinoceros, and elephants, or less than 6 feet high for other animals must be
approved in writing by the Administrator. The fence must be constructed so that
it protects the animals in the facility by restricting animals and unauthorized
persons from going through it or under it and having contact with the animals in
the facility, and so that it can function as a secondary containment system for
the animals in the facility. It must be of sufficient distance from the outside of
the primary enclosure to prevent physical contact between animals inside the
enclosure and animals or persons outside the perimeter fence. Such fences less
than 3 feet in distance from the primary enclosure must be approved in writing
by the Administrator.

You failed to have a perimeter fence of sufficient height, and
constructed to protect the animals in the facility by restricting
animals and unauthorized persons from going through it or under it
and having contact with the animals in the facility, and so that it can
function as a secondary containment system. At least one gate in the
perimeter fence was less than 8 feet in height. Vegetation grew into
or adjacent to the perimeter fence in some areas, and in one area, tree
branches/vines had grown into and around the barbed wire kick-ins,
resulting in drooping and/or damaged wires.

The penalty for the alleged violation(s) described above is $22,850.

Reference Number: CA150065-
An Equal Opportunity Provider and Employer AC

Issuance Date: August 22, 2016
Version: Final

payment online:

Click on Agency List.

Customers (2nd listing).

9. Print confirmation screen as your receipt.

Specialist.

SETTLEMENT AGREEMENT
Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you violated the Animal Welfare Act (7 U.S.C. § 2131 et seq.)
(AWA), as described in the attached Settlement Agreement. Our agency, the
Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing
the AWA, and other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and
plant pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may impose civil
penalties of up to $10,000, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Settlement Agreement. We are offering you the opportunity to resolve this matter
by paying an amount that is much lower than the maximum civil penalty.

What are the terms of the Settlement Agreement?

You should review the information in this Settlement Agreement, including the
citation and notification of penalty.

If you agree to waive your right to a hearing and pay the penalty, then do the
following:

o Pay the amount due, $2,750, by September 23, 2016. You can
pay by check, money order, or credit card. For your convenience,
we have included additional instructions for making payments.

o If you are unable to pay the full amount due by September 23,
2016, you may be eligible for a payment plan. To request a
payment plan, you must use the enclosed form to submit a written
response to this letter by September 23, 2016, that indicates you
wish to pay the penalty and waive your right to a hearing. You
must also submit a copy of your most recent federal tax return. As
part of your response, please include a phone number and an email
address so that we may contact you.

Reference Number: CA150144-
An Equal Opportunity Provider and Employer AC

Issuance Date: September 21.
2016

USDA

What are my other options?

If you do not agree with the terms of this Settlement Agreement, submit a written
request for a hearing, with your Reference Number, to our office by September
23, 2016, at 4700 River Rd., Unit 85, Riverdale, MD, 20737.

What happens if I fail to respond?

If we do not receive a payment or hearing request from you by September 23,
2016, we will forward this matter to our Office of the General Counsel for
litigation.

What should I do if I need help?

If you have any questions concerning this letter, contact Robert Randen at (301)
851-2785, or call our main office at (301) 851-2948.

17-00922_000077

USDA
USDA

Lockwood Animal Rescue Center
DBA: New England Animal Rescue
Center

15660 Curtis Trail

Frazier Park, CA 93225

CITATION AND NOTIFICATION OF PENALTY

We believe that you violated the Animal Welfare Act (7 U.S.C. § 2131 et seq.)
(AWA), as described below.

Date of Violation: Between November 2014 and March 2015

9 C.F.R. § 2.40(b)(3) Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care
(dealers and exhibitors).

(b) Each dealer or exhibitor shall establish and maintain programs of adequate
veterinary care that include:

(3) Daily observation of all animals to assess their health and well-being;
Provided, however, that daily observation of animals may be accomplished by
someone other than the attending veterinarian; and Provided, further, That a
mechanism of direct and frequent communication is required so that timely and
accurate information on problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being is
conveyed to the attending veterinarian.

You failed to establish a mechanism of direct and frequent
communication with the attending veterinarian. Several wolf hybrids
died between November 2014 and March 2015, most of whom were
humanely euthanized after you took them to a nearby veterinary
clinic for treatment. You did not inform your attending veterinarian
about their conditions, treatments, or deaths in a timely manner.

Date of Violation: December 3, 2014

9 C.F.R. § 3.1(a) Housing facilities, general.

(a) Structure; construction. Housing facilities for dogs and cats must be
designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound. They must be kept
in good repair, and they must protect the animals from injury, contain the
animals securely, and restrict other animals from entering.

You failed to construct and maintain housing facilities so that they
were structurally sound and protected the animals from injury. You
built eleven shelters on top of pallets to elevate them from the
ground; however, the shelters did not entirely cover the pallets,
leaving large gaps that could injure an animal’s legs and/or feet.

Reference Number: CA150144-
An Equal Opportunity Provider and Employer AC

Issuance Date: September 21.
2016
Version: Revision



## Enforcement Records-AWA and HPA-Sept to Oct 2016_page_18
USDA
USDA

Date of Violation: December 3, 2014

9 C.F_R. § 3.1(e) Housing facilities, general.

(e) Storage. Supplies of food and bedding must be stored in a manner that
protects the supplies from spoilage, contamination, and vermin infestation. The
supplies must be stored off the floor and away from the walls, to allow cleaning
underneath and around the supplies. Foods requiring refrigeration must be
stored accordingly, and all food must be stored in a manner that prevents
contamination and deterioration of its nutritive value. All open supplies of food
and bedding must be kept in leakproof containers with tightly fitting lids to
prevent contamination and spoilage. Only food and bedding that is currently
being used may be kept in the animal areas. Substances that are toxic to the
dogs or cats but are required for normal husbandry practices must not be stored
in food storage and preparation areas, but may be stored in cabinets in the
animal areas.

You failed to store and maintain animal food in a manner that
protected it from spoilage and contamination. APHIS observed:
1) A freezer where meat was stored needed to be cleaned.

2) A lack of organization in one freezer of the new and older meat.
3) Knives used to cut meat had bits of meat still on them and the
cutting board was covered in blood and other liquids.

Date of Violation: December 3, 2014

9 C.F.R. § 3.4(b)(3) Outdoor housing facilities.

(b) Shelter from the elements. Outdoor facilities for dogs or cats must include
one or more shelter structures that are accessible to each animal in each outdoor
facility, and that are large enough to allow each animal in the shelter structure
to sit, stand, and lie in a normal manner, and to turn about freely. In addition to
the shelter structures, one or more separate outside areas of shade must be
provided, large enough to contain all the animals at one time and protect them
from the direct rays of the sun. Shelters in outdoor facilities for dogs or cats
must contain a roof, four sides, and a floor, and must:

(3) Be provided with a wind break and rain break at the entrance

You failed to provide shelters with a wind and rain break at the
entrance. None of the wooden shelters had wind and rain breaks.

Date of Violation: December 3, 2014

9 C.F.R. § 3.11(c) Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
(c) Housekeeping for premises. Premises where housing facilities are located,
including buildings and surrounding grounds, must be kept clean and in good

USDA

repair to protect the animals from injury, to facilitate the husbandry practices
required in this subpart, and to reduce or eliminate breeding and living areas for
rodents and other pests and vermin. Premises must be kept free of
accumulations of trash, junk, waste products, and discarded matter. Weeds,
grasses, and bushes must be controlled so as to facilitate cleaning of the
premises and pest control, and to protect the health and well-being of the
animals.

You failed to keep the premises free of accumulations of trash, junk,
waste products, and discarded matter. Debris from meat packs was
strewn across the ground outside the food preparation area.

Date of Violation: On or about February 14-24, 2015

9 C.F.R. § 2.40(b)(3) Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care
(dealers and exhibitors).

(b) Each dealer or exhibitor shall establish and maintain programs of adequate
veterinary care that include:

(3) Daily observation of all animals to assess their health and well-being;
Provided, however, that daily observation of animals may be accomplished by
someone other than the attending veterinarian; and Provided, further, That a
mechanism of direct and frequent communication is required so that timely and
accurate information on problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being is
conveyed to the attending veterinarian.

You failed to establish a mechanism of direct and frequent
communication with the attending veterinarian. You observed that
Tahzay, a 13-15 year old male wolf dog hybrid, was gagging,
drooling, and vomiting, and was not eating. You brought him inside
for observation and to feed him a bland diet, but did not contact your
attending veterinarian. On February 16, 2015, you took him to a
nearby veterinary clinic because he was gagging, vomiting, and not
eating. The veterinarian prescribed an antibiotic and an anti-nausea
medication and you brought him back to your facility. On February
24, 2015, you took Tahzay back to the veterinary clinic after he did
not respond to the medications and his condition declined. Due to his
age and poor health, Tahzay was euthanized. You did not notify the
attending veterinarian about Tahzay’s condition during his illness.

Date of Violation: March 24, 2015

9 C.F.R. § 3.11(c) Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.

(c) Housekeeping for premises. Premises where housing facilities are located,
including buildings and surrounding grounds, must be kept clean and in good
repair to protect the animals from injury, to facilitate the husbandry practices
required in this subpart, and to reduce or eliminate breeding and living areas for
rodents and other pests and vermin. Premises must be kept free of

accumulations of trash, junk, waste products, and discarded matter. Weeds,
grasses, and bushes must be controlled so as to facilitate cleaning of the
premises and pest control, and to protect the health and well-being of the
animals.

You failed to control weeds, grasses, and bushes. Twelve of the
older, non-updated large enclosures of dog hybrids had excessively
dense trees and shrubs.

The penalty for the alleged violation(s) described above is $2,750.

How To Pay The Penalty

You may pay your penalty immediately through secure online transactions or
phone using American Express, Discover, Diners Club, Master Card, and Visa, or
by U.S. Mail using a check, cashier’s check, or money order.

payments through secure online payments. To submit your credit card
payment online:
1. Log on to https://www.pay.gov.
Click on Agency List.

Click on Department of Agriculture.
Click on Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service —- APHIS
Customers (2nd listing).
7. Complete the required information and submit the form.
8. Enter payment information and submit your payment.
9. Print confirmation screen as your receipt.

Phone. To make a credit card payment by phone:
1. Call (612) 336-3264 and speak to a Debt Management
Specialist.
2. State your Reference Number CA150144-AC.
3. Submit your credit card information.

U.S. Mail. To make a payment by check, cashier’s check, or money
order:
1. Make the check, cashier’s check, or money order payable to the
Treasurer of the United States.
2. Write the Reference Number CA150144-AC on your check,
cashier’s check, or money order.

SETTLEMENT AGREEMENT

Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you violated the Animal Welfare Act (7 U.S.C. § 2131 et seq.)
(AWA), as described in the attached Settlement Agreement. Our agency, the
Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing
the AWA, and other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and
plant pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may impose civil
penalties of up to $10,000, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Settlement Agreement. We are offering you the opportunity to resolve this matter
by paying an amount that is much lower than the maximum civil penalty.

What are the terms of the Settlement Agreement?

You should review the information in this Settlement Agreement, including the
citation and notification of penalty.

If you agree to waive your right to a hearing and pay the penalty, then do the
following:

oO Pay the amount due, $5,600, by July 25, 2016. You can pay by
check, money order, or credit card. For your convenience, we
have included additional instructions for making payments.

o If you are unable to pay the full amount due by July 25, 2016, you
may be eligible for a payment plan. To request a payment plan,
you must use the enclosed form to submit a written response to this
letter by July 25, 2016, that indicates you wish to pay the penalty
and waive your right to a hearing. You must also submit a copy of
your most recent federal tax return. As part of your response,
please include a phone number and an email address so that we
may contact you.

Reference Number: KS150003-
An Equal Opportunity Provider and Employer AC

Issuance Date: June 23. 2016
Version: Final

CITATION AND NOTIFICATION OF PENALTY

We believe that you violated the Animal Welfare Act (7 U.S.C. § 2131 et seq.)
(AWA), as described below.

Date of Violation: June 19, 2014

9 C.F.R. § 2.40(b)(2) Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care
(dealers and exhibitors).

(b) Each dealer or exhibitor shall establish and maintain programs of adequate
veterinary care that include:

(2) The use of appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat
diseases and injuries.

You failed to provide adequate veterinary care and use appropriate
methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries.
APHIS observed the following:

1) A black and tan adult male German Shepherd (microchip
AO1483334) had moist, swollen red skin between the toes of all four
feet, and appeared to walk tenderly at times on all four feet.

2) A buff colored adult female Lhasa Apso (microchip 048 586 088)
was holding up her right foreleg whenever she was at rest.

Date of Violation: September 8, 2014

9 C.F.R. § 2.40(b)(2) Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care
(dealers and exhibitors).

(b) Each dealer or exhibitor shall establish and maintain programs of adequate
veterinary care that include:

(2) The use of appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat
diseases and injuries.

You failed to provide adequate veterinary care and use appropriate
methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries.
APHIS observed the following:

1) An adult male Shiba Inu (microchip 448 793 780) with a swollen
mass of tissue between the middle toes on the right rear foot. The dog
was unable to bear any weight on the foot.

2) An adult female chocolate Labrador Retriever (microchip 079 275

CITATION AND NOTIFICATION OF PENALTY

We believe that you violated the Animal Welfare Act (7 U.S.C. § 2131 et seq.)
(AWA), as described below.

Date of Violation: August 5, 2013

9 C.F.R. § 3.1(c)(1)(ii) Housing facilities, general. Surfaces. General
requirements. The surfaces of housing facilities including houses, dens, and
other furniture-type fixtures and objects within the facility must be constructed
in a manner and made of materials that allow them to be readily cleaned and
sanitized, or removed or replaced when worn or soiled. Interior surfaces and
any surfaces that come in contact with dogs or cats must be free of jagged edges
or sharp points that might injure the animals.

You failed to properly construct an enclosure in the whelping facility
which contained two puppies, as evidenced by cut wires with sharp
points.

Date of Violation: June 3, 2014

9 C.F.R. § 2.40(b)(2) Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care
(dealers and exhibitors). Each dealer or exhibitor shall establish and maintain
programs of adequate veterinary care that include the use of appropriate
methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries, and the
availability of emergency, weekend, and holiday care.

You failed to provide adequate veterinary care for one female Silky
Terrier (#157) nursing two puppies, who was very thin with easily
palpable ribs and defined vertebrae showing.

Date of Violation: July 16, 2014

9 C.F.R. § 2.40(b)(2) Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care
(dealers and exhibitors). Each dealer or exhibitor shall establish and maintain
programs of adequate veterinary care that include the use of appropriate
methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries, and the
availability of emergency, weekend, and holiday care.

You failed to provide adequate veterinary care for the following
animals:

1) One Silky Terrier (#165) who had knotted, matted hair pulling at

and

Date of Violation: January 12, 2015

9 C.F.R. § 2.40(b)(2) Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care
(dealers and exhibitors). Each dealer or exhibitor shall establish and maintain
programs of adequate veterinary care that include the use of appropriate
methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries, and the
availability of emergency, weekend, and holiday care.

You failed to provide adequate veteriary care for a male boxer
(#121) who had a deep, harsh, non-productive cough upon exertion.

Date of Violation: April 30, 2015

9 C.F_R. § 2.126(b) Access and inspection of records and property; submission
of itineraries. The use of a room, table, or other facilities necessary for proper
examination of the records and inspection of the property or animals must be
extended to APHIS officials by the dealer, exhibitor, intermediate handler or
carrier, and a responsible adult shall be made available to accompany APHIS
officials during the inspection process.

Date of Violation: June 15, 2015

extended to APHIS officials by the dealer, exhibitor, intermediate handler or

programs of adequate veterinary care that include the use of appropriate

## Enforcement Records-AWA and HPA-Sept to Oct 2016_page_32
USDA
USDA

You failed to provide adequate veterinary care for the following
animals:

1) One Chihuahua (#190) who had a torn left ear with the ear flap
dangling:

2) One Shih Tzu (#187) who was periodically shaking and rubbing its
head. The right ear was hot to the touch and had a black discharge in
the ear canal;

3) One Pomeranian (#84) who had patches of matted hair along the
belly and behind the ears. The dog’s penis and prepuce looked red,
inflamed, and irritated; and

4) One Silky Terrier (#162) who had long toenails that were starting
to curve.

Date of Violation: June 24, 2015

9 C.F.R. § 3.1(a) Housing facilities, general. Structure; construction. Housing
facilities for dogs and cats must be designed and constructed so that they are
structurally sound. They must be kept in good repair, and they must protect the
animals from injury, contain the animals securely, and restrict other animals
from entering.

You failed to construct and maintain enclosures so that they were
structurally sound, protected the animals from injury, contained the
animals securely, and restricted other animals from entering. The
divider between two enclosures detached from the main building,
which created an opening and allowed the dogs in the two enclosures
access to each other. A dog (#110) in one of the enclosures died,
apparently from a fight between the dogs, as evidenced by puncture
wounds on its body.

Date of Violation: June 24, 2015

9 C.F.R. § 3.7 Dogs and cats that are housed in the same primary enclosure
must be compatible.

You failed to ensure that dogs housed in the same primary enclosure
were compatible. You housed two Chihuahuas together that were not
compatible. One of the Chihuahuas (#190) had a torn ear and the tip
of the left ear flap was dangling. The ear flap showed signs of dried
blood and the edges of the wound had started to tum black. You had
not noticed this at the time of the inspection, and indicated that it may
have been the result of a fight between the dogs.

The penalty for the alleged violation(s) described above is $2,550.

How To Pay The Penalty
You may pay your penalty immediately through secure online transactions or
phone using American Express, Discover, Diners Club, Master Card, and Visa, or

by U.S. Mail using a check, cashier’s check, or money order.

Online. Pay.gov allows you to make deferred and recurring credit card
payments through secure online payments. To submit your credit card

payment online:
1. Log on to https://www.pay.gov.
2. Click on Agency List.
3. Click on “A” in Index.
4. Click on Agriculture Department.
5. Click on Department of Agriculture.
6. Click on Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service —- APHIS

Customers (2nd listing).
7. Complete the required information and submit the form.
8. Enter payment information and submit your payment.
9. Print confirmation screen as your receipt.

Phone. To make a credit card payment by phone:
1. Call (612) 336-3264 and speak to a Debt Management
Specialist.
2. State your Reference Number MO150062-AC.
3. Submit your credit card information.

U.S. Mail. To make a payment by check, cashier’s check, or money
order:
1. Make the check, cashier’s check, or money order payable to the
Treasurer of the United States.
2. Write the Reference Number MO150062-AC on your check,
cashier’s check, or money order.
3. Mail your payment to:
USDA — APHIS — GENERAL MO150062-AC
P.O. Box 979043
St. Louis, MO 63197-9000

If You Are Unable To Pay In Full

Complete the attached form and return it to our office to request a payment plan.
Please be prepared to provide us with copies of your most recent federal tax return
so that we may determine whether you are eligible for a payment plan.

SETTLEMENT AGREEMENT

Re: Reference number OH150007-AC
Dear Mr. McGuire:

We believe that you violated the Animal Welfare Act, 7 U.S.C. § 2131 ef seq.
(“AWA”), as described in the enclosed Settlement Agreement. Our agency, the
Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing
the AWA to ensure the welfare of animals.

Violations of the AWA can have serious and costly impacts, detrimental to
animals and the public interest. After providing you with an opportunity for a
hearing, we may pursue civil penalties of up to $10,000, or other sanctions, for
each violation described in this Settlement Agreement. However, instead of
pursuing a civil penalty or other sanctions at this time, we are offering you the
opportunity to resolve this matter by agreeing to meet the terms specified in the
enclosed Settlement Agreement.

What are the terms of the Settlement Agreement?

Briefly, the Settlement Agreement provides that APHIS will not initiate formal
enforcement action for the alleged violations outlined in the Settlement
Agreement, if:

i. You agree to a revocation of your AWA license, and permanent
disqualification from obtaining an AWA license in the future.

2 You agree to sell, donate, and/or transfer ownership of your regulated
animals within 12 weeks from the date you sign the Settlement
Agreement. You will need to request a one-time exemption from the
licensing requirements to disperse your regulated animals if you 1) do
not currently hold a license, or 2) disperse them after signing this
Settlement Agreement. You may also request an exemption to retain a

Reference Number: OH150007-
An Equal Opportunity Provider and Employer AC

Issuance Date: May 17, 2016
Version: Final



## Enforcement Records-AWA and HPA-Sept to Oct 2016_page_36
SDA

—
—_

ME unites states Department of Agriculture

reasonable number of animals that are your personal pets. To request
an exemption, you should contact Teany Gerkin with Animal Care at
(919) 855-7116.

3. You agree to allow Animal Care to take an inventory of the regulated
animals currently present at your facility. You also agree to allow
Animal Care to confirm that you have sold, donated, and transferred
ownership of your regulated animals (other than animals for which you
request an exemption) within the 12-week period, by allowing Animal
Care to take an inventory of the regulated animals present at your
facility and providing Animal Care with ownership transfer records.

4. You acknowledge that the Secretary has jurisdiction over activities
govermmed by the AWA and waive your opportunity for a hearing in this
matter.

5. You agree that your failure to comply with the terms of the Settlement

Agreement will void the Settlement Agreement, and allow APHIS to
pursue any and all remedies and sanctions.

The above is a summary of the terms in the Settlement Agreement. You should
review the Settlement Agreement in its entirety.

When must I respond?

If you agree to meet the terms of the Settlement Agreement, sign the Settlement
Agreement and send it to our office by June 17, 2016: USDA, APHIS, IES
OH150007-AC, 4700 River Road, Unit 85, Riverdale, MD 20737-1234. We
reserve the right to withdraw the Settlement Agreement if you fail to comply with
any of the terms.

What are my other options?

e If you do not agree with the terms of the Settlement Agreement, you may
submit a written request for a hearing, with your Reference Number, to
our office by June 17, 2016: USDA, APHIS, IES OH150007-AC, 4700
River Road, Unit 85, Riverdale, MD 20737-1234.

e Alternatively, if you are interested in resolving this matter by paying a
monetary civil penalty instead of agreeing to the terms specified in the
Settlement Agreement, please contact our office using the telephone
numbers below.

Zama small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding APHIS’s
enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?

APHIS always welcomes comments on how it can better assist small
businesses. If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and
plant health laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small
Business Ombudsperson, at 301-851-2948. If you would prefer to comment to
someone outside APHIS, you may contact the Small Business Regulatory
Enforcement Ombudsperson at http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email
ombudsman@sba.gov, or toll free at 1-888-REG-FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s
office receives comments from small businesses and annually evaluates federal
agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs of
small businesses.

SETTLEMENT AGREEMENT

THIS AGREEMENT is entered into by the United States Department of
Agriculture, Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (“APHIS”), and Kord
McGuire, with reference to the following facts:

1. At all times mentioned herein, Kord McGuire operated as an
Exhibitor under the Animal Welfare Act (7 U.S.C. § 2131 ef seq.) (the “AWA”) at
the facility located at 385 Quinn Road, West Alexandria, OH 45381.

2. APHIS has documented evidence of Kord McGuire’s non-
compliance with the AWA and the regulations promulgated thereunder (9 C_F_R.
§ 1.1 ef seq.), and specifically, has documented evidence of Kord McGuire’s
failure to provide adequate veterinary care, provide adequate heat and shelter
during periods of inclement weather, provide sufficient quantities of food, and
provide shelter free from sharp point that could mjure animals as required by the
AWA regulations and AWA standards for the humane handling and treatment of
animals (9 C.F.R. §§ 2.40(b)(2), 2.40(b)(3), 3.77(a), 3.80(a)(2)(i), 3.125(a),
3.127(b), 3.127(c), and 3.129(a)).

3. APHIS has not instituted an administrative enforcement action
based on the findings described above in paragraph 2.

4. APHIS and Kord McGuire have determined to settle the issues
related to the potential violations of the AWA and the regulations and standards
issued thereunder, as described above.

NOW, THEREFORE, it is agreed as follows:

5: Kord McGuire adimits that the Secretary has jurisdiction in this
matter, and waives oral hearing and further procedure.

6. Kord McGuire consents and agrees to the following:

Reference Number: OH150007-
An Equal Opportunity Provider and Employer AC

Issuance Date: May 17, 2016
Version: Final



## Enforcement Records-AWA and HPA-Sept to Oct 2016_page_39
17-00922 000133

a. Kord McGuire agrees to sell, donate, and/or transfer
ownership and possession of any regulated animals on his premises,
regardless of ownership, within twelve (12) weeks from the date Kord
McGuire signs this Settlement Agreement.

b. Animal Care will, upon written request, grant a one-
time exemption from the licensing requirements for the transfer,
movement, and/or sale of any regulated animal that Kord McGuire holds
at the time Kord McGuire signs this Settlement Agreement, to include the
transportation of animals that are less than eight (8) weeks of age.

6: Animal Care will, upon written request, grant an
exemption for Kord McGuire to retain a reasonable number of animals
that are maintained for his own personal use and enjoyment, provided that
the laws of the jurisdiction where Kord McGuire lives allow him to keep
the animals.

d. At a time that is mutually agreeable to both parties,
Animal Care shall take an inventory of the regulated animals currently
present at Kord McGuire’s facility to determine his existing inventory of
animals, and Animal Care shall take a second inventory of the regulated
animals present at Kord McGuire’s facility within twelve (12) weeks from
the date Kord McGuire signs this Settlement Agreement to verify
compliance with paragraph (a) above. Kord McGuire shall not
unreasonably withhold his consent to a time and date for Animal Care to
conduct the inventories. Kord McGuire shall document all sales,
donations, and transfers of ownership and provide copies of those
documents to Animal Care within twelve (12) weeks from the date Kord

McGuire signs this Settlement Agreement.

e. As of the date Kord McGuire signs this Settlement

Agreement, AWA license 31-C-0031 is hereby revoked.

f. Kord McGuire and any partnerships, firms,

and regulations issued thereunder (9 C.F.R. § 1.1 ef seq.), either directly or

below, and that APHIS shall have the right to immediately institute enforcement
proceedings against Kord McGuire based upon the non-compliant items
documented at 385 Quinn Road, West Alexandria, OH 45381, in connection with
animal welfare investigation OH150007-AC, and any future violations, and to
pursue any and all remedies available to APHIS under the AWA.

8. For and in consideration of Kord McGuire’s agreements and
actions described in paragraph 6 above, and the promises and admissions of Kord
McGuire set forth herein, APHIS agrees not to institute an administrative or civil
enforcement action against Kord McGuire in connection with the alleged AWA
violations documented in animal welfare investigation OH150007-AC.

APHIS and Kord McGuire warrant and represent that their respective
representatives, whose signatures appear below, have the authority to execute this
Settlement Agreement and to bind each of the parties, respectively, to this

Settlement Agreement.

AGREEMENT

THIS AGREEMENT is entered into between the Animal and Plant Health Inspection
Service, United States Department of Agriculture (APHIS), and Spirit of the Hills Wildlife
Sanctuary, a South Dakota corporation (Spirit of the Hills), with reference to the following facts:

I. At all times mentioned herein, Spirit of the Hills was an exhibitor, as that term Is
defined in the Animal Welfare Act (7 U.S.C. 2131 et seq. (AWA or Act) and held AWA license
46-C-0053, and operated a zoo, as that term is defined in the regulations promulgated under the
Act (9 C.F.R. Parts 1 and 2) (Regulations), located at 500 Tinton Road, Spearfish, SD 57783.

H. On September 28, 2016, and September 30, 2016, APHIS conducted inspections

of the animals, facilities and records at Spirit of the Hills (the September 2016 Inspections),

which inspections revealed evidence of non-compliance with the Regulations and failures tor
meet the minimum standards promulgated under the Act (9 C.F.R. Part 3)(Standards).

Il. APHIS and Spirit of the Hills have now determined to compromise and settle the
issues between them related to the potential violations of the Act and the Regulations based on
the September 2016 Inspections. Pursuant to section 2149 of the Act (7 U.S.C. § 2149), if the

Secretary of Agriculture believes that a licensee has violated the Act or the Regulations, the

Secretary is authorized to suspend or revoke the licensee’s license and to assess civil peng Ities,

ied to have occurred.

after notice and an opportunity for a hearing, if such violations are determi

l'o date, APHIS has not taken any enforcement action against Spirit of the Hills based on the
ber 2016 Inspections.
NOW, THEREFORE, it is agreed as follows:

A. Spirit of the Hills admits that the Secretary has jurisdiction in this matter, and

waives oral hearing and further procedure.



## Enforcement Records-AWA and HPA-Sept to Oct 2016_page_43
B. For and in consideration of the agreement by APHIS described in paragraph C
below, Spirit of the Hills consents and agrees to the following:
I. AWA license 46-C-0053 is hereby revoked effective October a. 2016.
2. The failure by Spirit of the Hills to comply with any of the terms of this
Agreement shall automatically void paragraph C below.
C, For and in consideration of the agreement by Spirit of the Hills described in
paragraph B above, APHIS consents and agrees not to institute an enforcement action under the
AWA against Spirit of the Hills based on or in connection with the September 2016 Inspections.

The parties agree that this Agreement shall have the same force and effect as an order

entered after a full hearing pursuant to the Act and the Rules of Practice Governing Formal
Adjudicatory Proceedings Instituted By the Secretary (7 C.F.R. §§ 1.130-1.151; 4.10-4.] 1).

IN WITNESS WHEREOF, this agreement is executed on October = , 2016.

U.S. DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE SPIRIT OF THE HILLS

SETTLEMENT AGREEMENT

Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you violated the Animal Welfare Act (7 U.S.C. § 2131 et seq.)
(AWA), as described in the attached Settlement Agreement. Our agency, the
Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing
the AWA, and other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and
plant pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may impose civil
penalties of up to $10,000, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Settlement Agreement. We are offering you the opportunity to resolve this matter
by paying an amount that is much lower than the maximum civil penalty.

What are the terms of the Settlement Agreement?

You should review the information in this Settlement Agreement, including the
citation and notification of penalty.

If you agree to waive your right to a hearing and pay the penalty, then do the
following:

o Pay the amount due, $33,000, by November 14, 2016. You can
pay by check, money order, or credit card. For your convenience,
we have included additional instructions for making payments.

o If you are unable to pay the full amount due by November 14,
2016, you may be eligible for a payment plan. To request a
payment plan, you must use the enclosed form to submit a written
response to this letter by November 14, 2016, that indicates you
wish to pay the penalty and waive your nght to a hearing. You
must also submit a copy of your most recent federal tax return. As
part of your response, please include a phone number and an email
address so that we may contact you.

Reference Number: TX160007-
An Equal Opportunity Provider and Employer AC

Issuance Date: October 13, 2016
Version: Final

17-00922_000235

i United States Department of Agriculture

What are my other options?

If you do not agree with the terms of this Settlement Agreement, submit a written
request for a hearing, with your Reference Number, to our office by November
14, 2016, at 4700 River Rd., Unit 85, Riverdale, MD, 20737.

What happens if I fail to respond?

If we do not receive a payment or hearing request from you by November 14,
2016, we will forward this matter to our Office of the General Counsel for
litigation.

What should I do if I need help?

If you have any questions concerning this letter, contact Robert Randen at (301)
851-2785, or call our main office at (301) 851-2948.

Tam a smail business owner and have comments or concerns regarding APHIS’s
enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?

APHIS always welcomes comments on how it can better assist small
businesses. If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and
plant health laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small
Business Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you would prefer to comment to
someone outside APHIS, you may contact the Small Business Regulatory
Enforcement Ombudsperson at http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email
ombudsman@sba.gov, or toll free at 1-888-REG-FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s
office receives comments from small businesses and annually evaluates federal

ME united states Department of Agriculture

University of Texas

Medical Branch at Galveston
301 University Blvd.
Galveston, TX 77550

CITATION AND NOTIFICATION OF PENALTY

We believe that you violated the Animal Welfare Act (7 U.S.C. § 2131 et seq.)
(AWA), as described below.

Date of Violation: March 13, 2013

9 C.F.R. § 2.131(b)(1) Handling of animals.

(b)(1) Handling of all animals shall be done as expeditiously and carefully as
possible in a manner that does not cause trauma, overheating, excessive
cooling, behavioral stress, physical harm, or unnecessary discomfort.

You failed to handle animals as carefully as possible. Five of forty
guinea pigs died when staff members stacked several enclosures on
top of each other and transferred them from one room to another.
The only ventilation for each enclosure was located on its top.

Date of Violation: On or about November 17, 2015 to December 15, 2015

9 C.F.R. § 2.31(c)(7) Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC).
(c) IACUC functions. With respect to activities involving animals, the [ACUC,
as an agent of the research facility, shall:

(7) Review and approve, require modifications in (to secure approval), or
withhold approval of proposed significant changes regarding the care and use of
animals in ongoing activities.

You failed to secure IACUC approval prior to making significant
changes regarding the care and use of animals used in ongoing
activities. Protocols 1507043 and 1507044 indicated that you would
increase animal observations at the onset of clinical signs, but forty-
nine animal records did not document these increased observations.
In addition, the scoring sheet used to record animal observations did
not correlate with the project specific scoring sheet approved for use
in these protocols.

Date of Violation: On or about November 24, 2015 to December 15, 2015

9 C.F.R. § 2.33(b)(3) Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care.

(b) Each research facility shall establish and maintain programs of adequate

veterinary care that include:

(3) Daily observation of all animals to assess their health and well-being:
Reference Number: TX160007-

An Equal Opportunity Provider and Employer AC

Issuance Date: October 13, 2016
Version: Final



## Enforcement Records-AWA and HPA-Sept to Oct 2016_page_48
SDA

—_
—_

ME united states Department of Agriculture

Provided, however, That daily observation of animals may be accomplished by
someone other than the attending veterinarian; and Provided, further, That a
mechanism of direct and frequent communication is required so that timely and
accurate information on problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being is
conveyed to the attending veterinarian

You failed to provide direct and frequent communications to the
attending veterinarian. Staff members did not notify the attending
veterinarian when nine of twenty-five guinea pigs used during
protocol 1507043 died. The protocol stated death was not the end
point of the study.

Date of Violation: On or about December 4-12, 2015

9 C.F.R. § 2.33(b)(3) Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care.

(b) Each research facility shall establish and maintain programs of adequate
veterinary care that include:

(3) Daily observation of all animals to assess their health and well-being:
Provided, however, That daily observation of animals may be accomplished by
someone other than the attending veterinarian; and Provided, further, That a
mechanism of direct and frequent communication is required so that timely and
accurate information on problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being is
conveyed to the attending veterinarian

You failed to provide direct and frequent communications to the
attending veterinarian. Staff members failed to notify the attending
veterinarian when ten of twenty-four guinea pigs used during
protocol 1507044 died. The protocol stated death was not the end
point of the study.

Date of Violation: January 20, 2016

9 C.F.R. § 2.131(b)(1) Handling of animals.

(b)(1) Handling of all animals shall be done as expeditiously and carefully as
possible in a manner that does not cause trauma, overheating, excessive
cooling, behavioral stress, physical harm, or unnecessary discomfort.

You failed to handle animals as carefully as possible. When staff
members moved a sheep from one enclosure to another enclosure, the
sheep jumped over the temporary ramp used to facilitate the
movement between the uneven surfaces of the enclosures. The sheep
sustained a leg fracture that required euthanasia.

The penalty for the alleged violation(s) described above is $33,000.

An Equal Opportunity Provider and Employer AC

SETTLEMENT AGREEMENT

Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you violated the Animal Welfare Act (7 U.S.C. § 2131 et seq.)
(AWA), as described in the attached Settlement Agreement. Our agency, the
Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing
the AWA, and other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and
plant pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may impose civil
penalties of up to $10,000, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Settlement Agreement. We are offering you the opportunity to resolve this matter
by paying an amount that is much lower than the maximum civil penalty.

What are the terms of the Settlement Agreement?

You should review the information in this Settlement Agreement, including the
citation and notification of penalty.

If you agree to waive your right to a hearing and pay the penalty, then do the
following:

o Pay the amount due, $1,000, by February 20, 2017. You can pay
by check, money order, or credit card. For your convenience, we
have included additional instructions for making payments.

o If you are unable to pay the full amount due by February 20,

2017, you may be eligible for a payment plan. To request a
payment plan, you must use the enclosed form to submit a written
response to this letter by February 20, 2017, that indicates you
wish to pay the penalty and waive your right to a hearmg. You
must also submit a copy of your most recent federal tax return. As
part of your response, please include a phone number and an email
address so that we may contact you.

Reference Number: W1160005-

An Equal Opportunity Provider and Employer AC

Issuance Date: January 18, 2017
Version: Final



## Enforcement Records-AWA and HPA-Sept to Oct 2016_page_50
17-00922_000242

USDA
USDA

What are my other options?

If you do not agree with the terms of this Settlement Agreement, submit a written
request for a hearing, with your Reference Number, to our office by February 20,
2017, at 4700 River Rd., Unit 85, Riverdale, MD, 20737.

What happens if I fail to respond?

If we do not receive a payment or hearing request from you by February 20,
2017, we will forward this matter to our Office of the General Counsel for
litigation.

What should I do if I need help?

If you have any questions concerning this letter, contact Robert Randen at (301)
851-2785, or call our main office at (301) 851-2948.

Iam a smail business owner and have comments or concerns regarding APHIS’s
enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?

APHIS always welcomes comments on how it can better assist small
businesses. If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and
plant health laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small
Business Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you would prefer to comment to
someone outside APHIS, you may contact the Small Business Regulatory
Enforcement Ombudsperson at http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email
ombudsman@sba.gov, or toll free at 1-888-REG-FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s
office receives comments from small businesses and annually evaluates federal
agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs of
small businesses.

Sincerely,

Cf th. $e

Steven M. Bennett, Director

aoeil

Racine Zoological Gardens
2131 N. Main Street
Racine, WI 53402

CITATION AND NOTIFICATION OF PENALTY

We believe that you violated the Animal Welfare Act (7 U.S.C. § 2131 et seq.)
(AWA), as described below.

Date of Violation: September 21, 2015

9 C.F.R. § 2.131(c)(1) Handling of animals.

(c)(1) During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal
risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with sufficient distance and/or
barriers between the animal and the general viewing public so as to assure the
safety of animals and the public.

You failed to handle an animal during public exhibition so there was
minimal risk of injury to the public with sufficient distance and/or
barriers between the animal and the public to assure the safety of the
animal and the public. You allowed members of the public to feed
two camels from a platform extending into the camel enclosure,
under the supervision of one zookeeper. The platform had a painted
line that you instructed the guests to stay behind. A three year old
child on the platform was bitten by a camel on the nght side of the
head, suffering a 2” gash.

The penalty for the alleged violation(s) described above is $1,000.

Reference Number: W1160005-
An Equal Opportunity Provider and Employer AC

Issuance Date: January 18, 2017
Version: Final

How To Pay The Penalty

You may pay your penalty immediately through secure online transactions or
phone using American Express, Discover, Diners Club, Master Card, and Visa, or
by U.S. Mail using a check, cashier’s check, or money order.

Online. Pay.gov allows you to make deferred and recurring credit card
payments through secure online payments. To submit your credit card
payment online:
1. Log on to https://www.pay.gov.
Click on Agency List.
Click on “A” in Index.
Click on Agriculture Department.
Click on Department of Agriculture.
Click on Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service —- APHIS
Customers (2nd listing).
7. Complete the required information and submit the form.
8. Enter payment information and submit your payment.
9. Print confirmation screen as your receipt.

Pi le BD

Phone. To make a credit card payment by phone:
1. Call (612) 336-3264 and speak to a Debt Management
Specialist.
2. State your Reference Number WI160005-AC.
3. Submit your credit card information.

U.S. Mail. To make a payment by check, cashier’s check, or money
order:
1. Make the check, cashier’s check, or money order payable to the
Treasurer of the United States.
2. Write the Reference Number WI160005-AC on your check,
cashier’s check, or money order.
3. Mail your payment to:
USDA — APHIS — GENERAL WI160005-AC
P.O. Box 979043
St. Louis, MO 63197-9000

If You Are Unable To Pay In Full

Please be prepared to provide us with copies of your most recent federal tax return
so that we may determine whether you are eligible for a payment plan.

OFFICIAL WARNING
Re: Reference number AL160021-AC
Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you violated the Horse Protection Act (15 U.S.C. § 1821 et seq.)
(HPA), as described in the attached Official Warning. Our agency, the Animal
and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing the
HPA, and other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and plant
pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may impose civil
penalties of up to $2,200, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Official Warning. Although we generally pursue penalties for this type of
violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this instance so long as

you comply, in the future. with laws that APHIS enforces.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you violate laws that APHIS
enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warning, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

What should I do if I have questions? If you have any questions concerning this
Official Warning, contact Kelly Ferrell at (301) 851-2755 or call our main office
at (301) 851-2948.

Zam a small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding
APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?
If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health
laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small Business
Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you prefer to comment to someone outside
APHIS, contact the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsperson at
http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba.gov, or 1-888-REG-

FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s office receives comments and annually evaluates
federal agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs
of small businesses.

Sincerely,

Voth et

Steven M. Bennett, Director

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed

15 U.S.C. § 1824(2)(B) Unlawful Acts. The following conduct is prohibited: The (A)
showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition, of any horse which is sore,
(B) entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition, any horse which is sore. (C) selling, auctioning or offering for sale, in any
horse sale or auction, any horse which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in
clause (A), (B), or (C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.”

You entered a horse named “All American Silver”, (entry number 257, class
number 36) for the purpose of showing in the 48th Annual Alabama Jubilee
Charity Horse Show, in Priceville, AL where the horse was found sore.

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warming or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C) selling, auctioning or offering for sale, in any
horse sale or auction, any horse which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in
clause (A), (B), or (C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.”

9 C.F.R. § 11.3 Horses subject to this rule that do not meet the following scar rule
criteria shall be considered to be “sore” and are subject to all prohibitions of section 5 of
the Act.

You allowed your horse “Cadillac’s Bum”, (entry number 608, class number
37) to be entered for the purpose of showing in the 48th Annual Alabama
Jubilee Charity Horse Show, in Priceville, AL where the horse was found sore
and in violation of the scar rule.

An Equa! Opportunity Provider and Employer Reference Number: AL160022-AC
Issuance Date: September 19. 2016
Version: Final

17-00922_000255

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

Charles Tooley

OFFICIAL WARNING
Re: Reference number AL160022-AC
Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you violated the Horse Protection Act (15 U.S.C. § 1821 et seq.)
(HPA), as described in the attached Official Waming. Our agency, the Animal
and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing the
HPA, and other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and plant
pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may impose civil
penalties of up to $2,200, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Official Warning. Although we generally pursue penalties for this type of
violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this instance so long as

you comply, in the future. with laws that APHIS enforces.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you violate laws that APHIS
enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warming, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

What should I do if I have questions? If you have any questions concerning this
Official Warning, contact Kelly Ferrell at (301) 851-2755 or call our main office
at (301) 851-2948.

Iam a small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding
APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?
If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health
laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small Business
Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you prefer to comment to someone outside
APHIS, contact the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsperson at
http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba.gov, or 1-888-REG-

FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s office receives comments and annually evaluates
federal agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs
of small businesses.

Sincerely,

Steven M. Bennett, Director
Investigative and Enforcement Services

UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE

CASE NUMBER:
AL160022-AC

VIOLATOR:
Charles Tooley

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: October 17, 2015

15 U.S.C. § 1824(2)(B) Unlawful Acts. The following conduct is prohibited: The (A)
showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition, of any horse which is sore,
(B) entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C) selling, auctioning or offering for sale, in any
horse sale or auction, any horse which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in
clause (A), (B), or (C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.”

9 C.F.R. § 11.3 Horses subject to this rule that do not meet the following scar rule
criteria shall be considered to be “sore” and are subject to all prohibitions of section 5 of
the Act.

You entered a horse named “Cadillac’s Bum”, (entry number 608, class
number 37) for the purpose of showing in the 48th Annual Alabama Jubilee
Charity Horse Show, in Priceville, AL where the horse was found sore and in
violation of the scar rule.

enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warning, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

Official Warning. Although we generally pursue penalties for this type of

you comply, in the future. with laws that APHIS enforces.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you violate laws that APHIS
enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warning, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

OFFICIAL WARNING
Re: Reference number AL160031-AC
Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you violated the Horse Protection Act (15 U.S.C. § 1821 et seq.)
(HPA), as described in the attached Official Waming. Our agency, the Animal
and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing the
HPA, and other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and plant
pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may impose civil
penalties of up to $2,200, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Official Warning. Although we generally pursue penalties for this type of
violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this instance so long as

you comply, in the future. with laws that APHIS enforces.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you violate laws that APHIS
enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warming, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

What should I do if I have questions? If you have any questions concerning this
Official Warning, contact David Dissinger at (301) 851-2803 or call our main
office at (301) 851-2948.

Iam a small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding
APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?
