The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: September 19, 2015
15 U.S.C. § 1824(2)(B) Unlawful acts - Entering

The following conduct is prohibited:

(2) The (A) showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition, of
any horse which is sore, (B) entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting
in any horse show or horse exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C) selling,
auctioning, or offering for sale, in any horse sale or auction, any horse which
is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in clause (A), (B), or (C)
respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.

Ryne Parker was the scheduled rider who entered for the purpose of showing,
“Ritz’s Special Temptation” (class number 26, entry number 972) while sore
and in violation of the scar rule at the 44th Annual Racking Horse World
Celebration in Decatur, Alabama.

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

4700 River Road, Unit 85
Riverdale, MD 20737

violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

OFFICIAL WARNING
Re: Reference number AL160034-AC
Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you violated the Horse Protection Act (15 U.S.C. § 1821 et seq.)
(HPA), as described in the attached Official Warning. Our agency, the Animal
and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing the
HPA, and other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and plant
pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may impose civil
penalties of up to $2,200, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Official Warning. Although we generally pursue penalties for this type of
violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this instance so long as

you comply, in the future. with laws that APHIS enforces.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you violate laws that APHIS
enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warning, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

What should I do if I have questions? If you have any questions concerning this
Official Warning, contact Kimberly Nichols at (301) 851-2739 or call our main
office at (301) 851-2948.

Zam a small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding
APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?
If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health
laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small Business
Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you prefer to comment to someone outside
APHIS, contact the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsperson at
http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba.gov, or 1-888-REG-

FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s office receives comments and annually evaluates
federal agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs
of small businesses.

Sincerely,

Voth et

Steven M. Bennett, Director

ANTMEN, " VIOLATOR:

VIOLATION OF FE AISREGULATIONS ae (Streel, City, Stale, ZIP
- Lo « le):

in ew hy Rockmart, GA 30153

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: September 19, 2015

15 U.S.C. § 1824(2) Unlawful Acts. The following conduct is prohibited: The (A)
showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition, of any horse which is sore,
(B) entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C) selling, auctioning or offering for sale, in any
horse sale or auction, any horse which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in
clause (A), (B), or (C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.”

9 C.F.R. § 11.3 Horses subject to this rule that do not meet the following scar rule
criteria shall be considered to be “sore” and are subject to all prohibitions of section 5 of
the Act.

You showed a horse named “The Divine Miss M” (Entry #926, Class #28) at
the 44th Annual RHBAA 2015 World Celebration in Decatur, AL while the
horse was sore and in violation of the scar rule.

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warming or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C) selling, auctioning or offering for sale, in any
horse sale or auction, any horse which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in
clause (A), (B), or (C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.”

9 C.F.R. § 11.3 Horses subject to this rule that do not meet the following scar rule
criteria shall be considered to be “sore” and are subject to all prohibitions of section 5 of
the Act.

You entered a horse named “Carolina Cash” (Entry #942, Class #37) for the
purpose of showing at the 44th Annual RHBAA 2015 World Celebration in
Decatur, AL while the horse was sore and in violation of the scar mule.

Date of Violation: September 19, 2015

15 U.S.C. § 1824(7) Unlawful Acts. The showing or exhibiting at a horse show or horse
exhibition; the selling or auctioning at a horse sale or auction; the allowing to be shown,
exhibited, or sold at a horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction; the entering
for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or exhibition; or offering for
sale at a horse show or auction, any horse which is wearing or bearing any equipment,
device, paraphernalia, or substance which the Secretary by regulation under section 1828
of this title prohibits to prevent the soring of horses.

You entered a horse named “Carolina Cash” (Entry 942, Class #37) for the
purpose of showing at the 44th Annual RHBAA 2015 World Celebration in
Decatur, AL where the horse was wearing a black foreign substance.

Reference Number: AL160035-
An Equa! Opportunity Provider and Employer AC

Issuance Date: October 19. 2016
Version: Final

## Enforcement Records-AWA and HPA-Sept to Oct 2016_page_100
USDA

Sa
ME unites states Department of Agriculture

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warming or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

APHIS OFFICIAL (Name): OFFICE ADDRESS:

## Enforcement Records-AWA and HPA-Sept to Oct 2016_page_101
Animal and Plant Health
Inspection Service

Marketing and
Regulatory Programs

Enforcement Services

4700 River Road

USDA

———
aI United States Department of Agriculture

VIA: USPS Certified Mail. Shipping: Ist October 19,
2016

Ann Southerland

128 Southerland Lane

White, TN 37890
OFFICIAL WARNING
Re: Reference number AL160035-AC
Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you violated the Horse Protection Act (15 U.S.C. § 1821 et seq.)
(HPA), as described in the attached Official Warning. Our agency, the Animal
and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing the
HPA, and other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and plant
pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may impose civil
penalties of up to $2,200, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Official Warning. Although we generally pursue penalties for this type of
violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this instance so long as

you comply, in the future. with laws that APHIS enforces.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you violate laws that APHIS
enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warning, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

What should I do if I have questions? If you have any questions concerning this
Official Warning, contact Kimberly Nichols at (301) 851-2739 or call our main
office at (301) 851-2948.

Zam a small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding
APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?
If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health
laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small Business
Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you prefer to comment to someone outside
APHIS, contact the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsperson at
http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba.gov, or 1-888-REG-

FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s office receives comments and annually evaluates
federal agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs
of small businesses.

Sincerely,

Voth et

Steven M. Bennett, Director

15 U.S.C. § 1824(2) Unlawful Acts. The following conduct is prohibited: The (A)
showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition, of any horse which is sore,
(B) entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C) selling, auctioning or offering for sale, in any
horse sale or auction, any horse which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in
clause (A), (B), or (C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.”

9 C.F.R. § 11.3 Horses subject to this rule that do not meet the following scar rule
criteria shall be considered to be “sore” and are subject to all prohibitions of section 5 of
the Act.

You allowed your horse “Carolina Cash” to be entered (Entry #942, Class
#37) for the purpose of showing at the 44th Annual RHBAA 2015 World
Celebration in Decatur, AL while the horse was sore and in violation of the
scar rule.

Date of Violation: September 19, 2015

15 U.S.C. § 1824(7) Unlawful Acts. The showing or exhibiting at a horse show or horse
exhibition; the selling or auctioning at a horse sale or auction; the allowing to be shown,
exhibited, or sold at a horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction; the entering
for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or exhibition; or offering for
sale at a horse show or auction, any horse which is wearing or bearing any equipment,
device, paraphernalia, or substance which the Secretary by regulation under section 1828
of this title prohibits to prevent the soring of horses.

You allowed your horse“Carolina Cash” to be entered (Entry 942, Class #37)
for the purpose of showing at the 44th Annual RHBAA 2015 World
Celebration in Decatur, AL where the horse was wearing a black foreign
substance.

enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil

enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil

OFFICIAL WARNING
Re: Reference number AL160037-AC
Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you violated the Horse Protection Act (15 U.S.C. § 1821 et seq.)
(HPA), as described in the attached Official Warning. Our agency, the Animal
and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing the
HPA, and other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and plant
pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may impose civil
penalties of up to $2,200, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Official Warning. Although we generally pursue penalties for this type of
violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this instance so long as

you comply, in the future. with laws that APHIS enforces.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you violate laws that APHIS
enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warning, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

What should I do if I have questions? If you have any questions concerning this
Official Warning, contact Kimberly Nichols at (301) 851-2739 or call our main
office at (301) 851-2948.

Zam a small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding
APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?
If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health
laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small Business
Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you prefer to comment to someone outside
APHIS, contact the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsperson at
http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba.gov, or 1-888-REG-

FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s office receives comments and annually evaluates
federal agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs
of small businesses.

Sincerely,

Voth et

Steven M. Bennett, Director

arres VIOLATOR:
A | ’ Mike Etheredge
SOF eb G

VIOLATION OF, FE AISREGULATIONS — (Street, City, State, ZIP
-  « ie):

in ew hy Louisville, MS 39339

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: September 19, 2015

15 U.S.C. § 1824(2) Unlawful Acts. The following conduct is prohibited: The (A)
showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition, of any horse which is sore,
(B) entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C) selling, auctioning or offering for sale, in any
horse sale or auction, any horse which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in
clause (A), (B), or (C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.”

9 C.F.R. § 11.3 Horses subject to this rule that do not meet the following scar rule

criteria shall be considered to be “sore” and are subject to all prohibitions of section 5 of
the Act.

You entered a horse named “The Thug” (Entry #75, Class #40) for the
purpose of showing at the 44th Annual RHBAA 2015 World Celebration in
Decatur, AL while the horse was sore and in violation of the scar rule.

Reference Number: AL160037-
An Equal Opportunity Provider and Employer AC

VIA: USPS Certified Mail. Shipping: Ist October 19,
2016

Mickey Groom

1302 Northgate Drive

Opelika, AL 36801
OFFICIAL WARNING
Re: Reference number AL160039-AC
Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you violated the Horse Protection Act (15 U.S.C. § 1821 et seq.)
(HPA), as described in the attached Official Warning. Our agency, the Animal
and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing the
HPA, and other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and plant
pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may impose civil
penalties of up to $2,200, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Official Warning. Although we generally pursue penalties for this type of
violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this instance so long as

you comply, in the future. with laws that APHIS enforces.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you violate laws that APHIS
enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warning, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

What should I do if I have questions? If you have any questions concerning this
Official Warning, contact Kimberly Nichols at (301) 851-2739 or call our main
office at (301) 851-2948.

Zam a small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding
APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?
If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health
laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small Business
Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you prefer to comment to someone outside
APHIS, contact the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsperson at
http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba.gov, or 1-888-REG-

FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s office receives comments and annually evaluates
federal agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs
of small businesses.

Sincerely,

Voth et

Steven M. Bennett, Director

United States Department of Agriculture

UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE CASE NUMBER:
ANIMAL AND PLANT HEALTH INSPECTION SERVICE AL160039-AC

arres VIOLATOR:
a old y' ’ Mickey Groom
ae a G

VIOLATION OF FE AISREGULATIONS ae (Streel, City, State, ZIP
wn wo” hes Opelika, AL 36801

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: September 25, 2015

15 U.S.C. § 1824(2) Unlawful Acts. The following conduct is prohibited: The (A)
showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition, of any horse which is sore,
(B) entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C) selling, auctioning or offering for sale, in any
horse sale or auction, any horse which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in
clause (A), (B), or (C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.”

9 C.F.R. § 11.3 Horses subject to this rule that do not meet the following scar rule
criteria shall be considered to be “sore” and are subject to all prohibitions of section 5 of
the Act.

You allowed your horse “It’s All About Ted” to be entered (Entry #477, Class
#138) for the purpose of showing at the 44th Annual RHBAA 2015 World
Celebration in Decatur, AL while the horse was sore and in violation of the
scar rule.

Reference Number: AL160039-
An Equal Opportunity Provider and Employer AC

## Enforcement Records-AWA and HPA-Sept to Oct 2016_page_141
USDA

Sa
ME unites states Department of Agriculture

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warming or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

you comply, in the future. with laws that APHIS enforces.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you violate laws that APHIS
enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warning, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests

that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official

2016

Tyler Parish

P.O. Box 323

Mt. Pleasant, TN 38474
OFFICIAL WARNING
Re: Reference number AL160042-AC
Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you violated the Horse Protection Act (15 U.S.C. § 1821 et seq.)
(HPA), as described in the attached Official Warning. Our agency, the Animal
and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing the
HPA, and other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and plant
pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may impose civil
penalties of up to $2,200, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Official Warning. Although we generally pursue penalties for this type of
violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this instance so long as

you comply, in the future. with laws that APHIS enforces.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you violate laws that APHIS
enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warning, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

What should I do if I have questions? If you have any questions concerning this
Official Warning, contact Kimberly Nichols at (301) 851-2739 or call our main
office at (301) 851-2948.

Zam a small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding
APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?
If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health
laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small Business
Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you prefer to comment to someone outside
APHIS, contact the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsperson at
http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba.gov, or 1-888-REG-

FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s office receives comments and annually evaluates
federal agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs
of small businesses.

Sincerely,

Voth et

Steven M. Bennett, Director

ANIMAL AND PLANT HEALTH INSPECTION SERVICE AL160042-AC

atliree VIOLATOR:
a ented » | Tyler Parish
SOF Ben 1G

VIOLATION OF FE AISREGULATIONS ene (Street, City, State, ZIP
-_ > i ms y ie):
2 \; a Ay Mt. Pleasant, TN 38474

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: September 25, 2015

15 U.S.C. § 1824(2) Unlawful Acts. The following conduct is prohibited: The (A)
showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition, of any horse which is sore,
(B) entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C) selling, auctioning or offering for sale, in any
horse sale or auction, any horse which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in
clause (A), (B), or (C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.”

9 C.F.R. § 11.3 Horses subject to this rule that do not meet the following scar rule
criteria shall be considered to be “sore” and are subject to all prohibitions of section 5 of
the Act.

You showed a horse named “Jose’s 38 Special (Entry #775, Class #145) at the
44th Annual RHBAA 2015 World Celebration in Decatur, AL while the horse
was sore and in violation of the scar rule.

## Enforcement Records-AWA and HPA-Sept to Oct 2016_page_161
USDA

Sa
ME unites states Department of Agriculture

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warming or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

VIOLATION OF FEDERAL REGULATIONS ADDRESS (Sieot, iV, Tae, ZIP
lee» Wages — 4 le):

McDowell, KY 41647

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: September 25, 2015

15 U.S.C. § 1824(2)(D) Unlawful Acts. The following conduct is prohibited: The (A)
showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition, of any horse which is sore,
(B) entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C) selling, auctioning or offering for sale, in any
horse sale or auction, any horse which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in
clause (A), (B), or (C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.”

15 U.S.C. § 1824(7) Unlawful Acts. The showing or exhibiting at a horse show or horse
exhibition ; the selling or auctioning at a horse sale or auction; the allowing to be shown,
exhibited, sold at a horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction the entering for
the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse exhibition: or offering
for sale at a horse sale or auction, any horse which is wearing or bearing any equipment,
device, paraphernalia, or substance which the Secretary by regulation under section 1828
of this title prohibits to prevent the soring of horses.

9 C.F.R. § 11(2)(c) Prohibition concerning exhibitors — Substances. All substances are
prohibited on the extremities above the hoof of any Tennessee Walking Horse or racking
horse while being show, exhibited, or offered for sale at any horse show, horse
exhibition, or horse sale or auction, except lubricants such as glycerine, petrolatum, and
mineral oil, or mixtures thereof. ...”

Reference Number: AL160044-
An Equal Opportunity Provider and Employer AC

Issuance Date: September 27,

2016

## Enforcement Records-AWA and HPA-Sept to Oct 2016_page_165
USDA

S—
ME united states Department of Agriculture

9 C.F.R. § 11(3)(b) Scar rule. The posterior surfaces of the pasterns (flexor surface),
including the sulcus of “pocket” may show bilateral areas of uniformly thickened
epithelial tissue if such areas are free of proliferating granuloma tissue, mritation,
moisture, edema, or other evidence of inflammation.

Danny Mead allowed his horse, “Sy Robertson” (entry number 720, class
number 152) to be entered for the purpose of showing in the 44th Annual
Racking Horse Breeders Association of America 2015 World Celebration in
Decatur, AL where the horse was found sore, in violation of the scar rule, and
bearing a prohibited substance on the pasterns during a pre-show inspection.

Diana Bowers

Elizabethton, TN 37643

OFFICIAL WARNING
Re: Reference number AL160045-AC
Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you violated the Horse Protection Act (15 U.S.C. § 1821 et seq.)
(HPA), as described in the attached Official Waming. Our agency, the Animal
and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing the
HPA, and other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and plant
pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may impose civil
penalties of up to $2,200, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Official Warning. Although we generally pursue penalties for this type of
violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this instance so long as

you comply, in the future. with laws that APHIS enforces.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you violate laws that APHIS
enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warming, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

What should I do if I have questions? If you have any questions concerning this
Official Warning, contact Kelly Ferrell at (301) 851-2755 or call our main office
at (301) 851-2948.

Iam a small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding
APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?
If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health
laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small Business
Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you prefer to comment to someone outside
APHIS, contact the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsperson at
http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba.gov, or 1-888-REG-

FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s office receives comments and annually evaluates
federal agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs
of small businesses.

Sincerely,

Steven M. Bennett, Director
Investigative and Enforcement Services


## Enforcement Records-AWA and HPA-Sept to Oct 2016_page_178
UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE
ANIMAL AND PLANT HEALTH INSPECTION SERVICE

CASE NUMBER:
AL160045-AC

VIOLATOR:
Diana Bowers

ADDRESS (Street, City, State, ZiP
Code):

Elizabethton, TN 37643

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: September 25, 2015

15 U.S.C. § 1824(2)(D) Unlawful Acts. The following conduct is prohibited: The (A)
showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition, of any horse which is sore,
(B) entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C) selling, auctioning or offering for sale, in any
horse sale or auction, any horse which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in
clause (A), (B), or (C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.”

9 C.F.R. § 11.3 Horses subject to this rule that do not meet the following scar rule
criteria shall be considered to be “sore” and are subject to all prohibitions of section 5 of
the Act.

You allowed your horse “Santana’s Bama Boy”, (entry number 467, class
number 152) to be entered for the purpose of showing in the 44th Annual
Racking Horse Breeders Association of America in Decatur, AL where the
horse was found sore and in violation of the scar rule.

An Equa! Opportunity Provider and Employer Reference Number: AL160045-AC
Issuance Date: October 13. 2016
Version: Final

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: September 26, 2015
15 U.S.C. § 1824(2)(B) Unlawful acts: Entering

The following conduct is prohibited:

(2) The (A) showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition,
of any horse which is sore, (B) entering for the purpose of showing or
exhibiting in any horse show or horse exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C)
selling, auctioning, or offering for sale, in any horse sale or auction, any horse
which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in clause (A), (B), or
(C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.

Bryan Barnhill was the scheduled rider who entered for the purpose of
showing, “A Strong Dollar Bill” (class # 155, entry # 329) while sore and in
violation of the scar rule at the 44th RHBAA Celebration horse show in
Decatur, Alabama.

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

penalties of up to $2,200, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Official Warning. Although we generally pursue penalties for this type of
violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this instance so long as

you comply, in the future. with laws that APHIS enforces.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you violate laws that APHIS
enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warming, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

What should I do if I have questions? If you have any questions concerning this
Official Warning, contact David Dissinger at (301) 851-2803 or call our main
office at (301) 851-2948.

Iam a small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding
APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?

## Enforcement Records-AWA and HPA-Sept to Oct 2016_page_200
UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE CASE NUMBER:
ANIMAL AND PLANT HEALTH INSPECTION SERVICE CA160193-AC

Fe VIOLATOR:
‘. o otis 2° " Greg Bryant
OFF FCIAL WARNENC

VIOLATION OF, ERALPREC ‘LON ADDRESS (Street, City, State, ZIP Code):

Devore Heights CA, 92407

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed below,
you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal Regulations:

Date of Violation: May 19, 2013
15 U.S.C. § 1824(7) Unlawful Acts

“The showing or exhibiting at a horse show or horse exhibition; the selling or
auctioning at a horse sale or auction; the allowing to be shown, exhibited, or sold
at a horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction; the entering for the
purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse exhibition; or
offering for sale at a horse sale or auction, any horse which is wearing or bearing
any equipment, device, paraphernalia, or substance which the Secretary by
regulation under Section 1828 of this title prohibits to prevent the soring of
horses.”

Date of Violation: May 19, 2013
9 C.F_R. § 11.2(c) Prohibition conceming exhibitors — Substances

“All substances are prohibited on the extremities above the hoof of any
Tennessee Walking Horse or racking horse while being shown, exhibited, or
offered for sale at any horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction,
except lubricants such as glycerine, petrolatum, and mineral oil, or mixtures
thereof...”

Greg Bryant entered, for the purpose of showing or exhibiting, the horse, “Tipsy
By Noon,” at the California Celebration in Pamona, CA, which was found to be
wearing a foreign substance.

An Equal Opportunity Provider and Employer Reference Number: CA160193-AC

17-00922_000392

Issuance Date: September 15, 2016
Version: Final

Date of Violation: May 19, 2013
15 U.S.C. § 1824(7) Unlawful Acts

“The showing or exhibiting at a horse show or horse exhibition; the selling or
auctioning at a horse sale or auction; the allowing to be shown, exhibited, or
sold at a horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction; the entering
for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition; or offering for sale at a horse sale or auction, any horse which is
wearing or bearing any equipment, device, paraphernalia, or substance which
the Secretary by regulation under Section 1828 of this title prohibits to prevent
the soring of horses.”

Date of Violation: May 19, 2013
9 C.F.R. § 11.2(c) Prohibition concerning exhibitors — Substances

“All substances are prohibited on the extremities above the hoof of any
Tennessee Walking Horse or racking horse while being shown, exhibited, or
offered for sale at any horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction,
except lubricants such as glycerine, petrolatum, and mineral oil, or mixtures
thereof...”

Marilee Moran allowed the entry of her horse at the show, for the purpose of
showing or exhibiting, the horse, “Tipsy By Noon,” at the California
Celebration in Pamona, CA, which was found to be wearing a foreign
substance.

OFFICIAL WARNING
Re: Reference number CA160198-AC
Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you violated the Horse Protection Act (15 U.S.C. § 1821 et seq.)
(HPA), as described in the attached Official Waming. Our agency, the Animal
and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing the
HPA, and other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and plant
pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may impose civil
penalties of up to $2,200, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Official Warning. Although we generally pursue penalties for this type of
violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this instance so long as

you comply, in the future. with laws that APHIS enforces.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you violate laws that APHIS
enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warming, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

What should I do if I have questions? If you have any questions concerning this
Official Warning, contact Edmund Grant at (301) 851-2752 or call our main
office at (301) 851-2948.

Iam a small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding
APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?
If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health
laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small Business
Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you prefer to comment to someone outside
APHIS, contact the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsperson at
http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba.gov, or 1-888-REG-

FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s office receives comments and annually evaluates
federal agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs
of small businesses.

Sincerely,

Steven M. Bennett, Director
Investigative and Enforcement Services

you comply, in the future. with laws that APHIS enforces.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you violate laws that APHIS
enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warming, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

What should I do if I have questions? If you have any questions concerning this
Official Warning, contact Edmund Grant at (301) 851-2752 or call our main
office at (301) 851-2948.

Iam a small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding
APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?
If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health
laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small Business
Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you prefer to comment to someone outside

http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba.gov, or 1-888-REG-

UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE

CASE NUMBER:
CA160200-AC

VIOLATOR:
Manuel Rodriguez

ADDRESS (Street, City, State, ZiP
Code):

Ontario, CA 91761

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: May 19, 2013
15 U.S.C. § 1824(7) Unlawful Acts

“The showing or exhibiting at a horse show or horse exhibition; the selling or
auctioning at a horse sale or auction; the allowing to be shown, exhibited, or
sold at a horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction; the entering
for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition; or offering for sale at a horse sale or auction, any horse which is
wearing or bearing any equipment, device, paraphernalia, or substance which
the Secretary by regulation under Section 1828 of this title prohibits to prevent
the soring of horses.”

Date of Violation: May 19, 2013
9 C.F.R. § 11.2(c) Prohibition concerning exhibitors — Substances

“All substances are prohibited on the extremities above the hoof of any
Tennessee Walking Horse or racking horse while being shown, exhibited, or
offered for sale at any horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction,
except lubricants such as glycerine, petrolatum, and mineral oil, or mixtures
thereof...”

Manuel Rodriguez entered, for the purpose of showing or exhibiting, the
horse, “A Sky Captain.” at the California Celebration in Pamona, CA, which
was found to be wearing a foreign substance.

SPOT Travel, LLC CT Corporation System

C/O SPOT Group Holdings, LLC
145 West 20th Street
New York, NY 10011

208 S. La Salle Street, Suite 814
Chicago, IL 60604

OFFICIAL WARNING
NOTICE OF ALLEGED VIOLATION

Re: Reference number IL150028-AC
Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you failed to comply with the Animal Welfare Act (7 U.S.C. §
2131 et seq.) (AWA), and its implementing regulations, as described in the
attached Official Warming. Our agency, the Animal and Plant Health Inspection
Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing the AWA, and regulations and
other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests and
diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may pursue civil
penalties of up to $10,000, or other sanctions, for each alleged violation described
in this Official Warning. Although we have authority to pursue penalties for this
type of alleged violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this
instance so long as you comply, in the future, with the AWA and regulations.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you fail to comply in the
future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil penalties for the
alleged violations described in this Official Warning, in addition to any penalties
we may pursue for any future violations.

What should I do if I have questions? If you have any questions concerning this
Official Warning, contact Roxanne Folk at (301) 851-2736 or call our main office
at (301) 851-2948.

Tam a small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding
APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?
If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health
laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small Business
Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you prefer to comment to someone outside
APHIS, contact the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsperson at
http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba. gov, or 1-888-REG-

FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s office receives comments and annually evaluates
federal agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs
of small businesses.

Sincerely,

Ch pee

Steven M. Bennett, Director
Investigative and Enforcement Services


## Enforcement Records-AWA and HPA-Sept to Oct 2016_page_223
USDA

l

UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE
ANIMAL AND PLANT HEALTH INSPECTION SERVICE

CASE NUMBER:
IL150028-AC

ALLEGED VIOLATOR:

SPOT Travel, LLC

C/O SPOT Group

Holdings, LLC
OFFICIAL. WARNING

NOTICE OF ALLEGED VIOLATION

ADDRESS (City, State, ZIP Code):
New York, NY 10011

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following alleged violation(s) of Federal
laws:

Date of Alleged Violation: June 18-19, 2015
9 C.F.R. § 2.131(b)(1) Handling of Animals.

You failed to handle animals as carefully as possible in a manner that did not
cause trauma, overheating, behavioral stress, physical harm, or unnecessary
discomfort. A shipment of four adult sugar gliders were scheduled for
transport by a carrier, in commerce, from Charlotte-Douglas International
Airport (CLT), routed through Chicago, Illinois (ORD), with a final
destination of Charleston, West Virginia (CRW). The carrier did not load the
animals onto their originally-scheduled flight from CLT to ORD, and
subsequently transported them on a later flight to ORD. Due to the missed
flight and weather-related delays, the sugar gliders did not make their
connection to CRW, and the carrier delivered them to you for holding
overnight at ORD. You did not visually observe the sugar gliders or provide
them with food or water. The sugar gliders resumed transit on a flight from
ORD to CRW the following day, and the consignee discovered that they were
dead when she picked them up at CRW. The necropsy performed on the sugar
gliders indicated that they died from probable heat stroke.

An Equal Opportunity Provider and Employer Reference Number: IL150028-AC
Issuance Date: November 14.

2016
Version: Final

17-00922_000415


## Enforcement Records-AWA and HPA-Sept to Oct 2016_page_224

a2

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) published federal
regulations to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and
plant pests and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and
costly impacts that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with
an Official Warming for the alleged violation(s) described above. This Official
Warning is not to be construed as a final agency action, or as an adjudicated finding of
a violation. If APHIS obtains evidence of any future violation of these federal
regulations, APHIS may pursue civil penalties, criminal prosecution, or other
sanctions for this alleged violation(s) and for any future violation(s). If you have any
questions concerning this Official Warning or alleged violation(s), please contact the
APHIS official listed in this notice.

UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE CASE NUMBER:

ANIMAL AND PLANT HEALTH INSPECTION SERVICE NC160021-AC
ai Ms VIOLATOR:
> Kerry DeArmond
OrfE

ADDRESS (Street, City, State, ZiP
Code):

Greer, SC 29651

VIOLATION OF

L wan
) _

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: October 9, 2015
15 U.S.C. § 1824(2)(D) Unlawful acts - Allowing

The following conduct is prohibited:

(2) The (A) showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition,
of any horse which is sore, (B) entering for the purpose of showing or
exhibiting in any horse show or horse exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C)
selling, auctioning, or offering for sale, in any horse sale or auction, any horse
which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in clause (A), (B), or
(C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.

Kerry DeArmond was the owner who allowed “Powerful Performance” (class
# 37, entry # 190) to be entered for the purpose of showing, while sore, at the
North Carolina Championship Walking Horse Show in Fletcher, North
Carolina.

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

OFFICE ADDRESS:
4700 River Road, Unit 85
Riverdale, MD 20737

DATE ISSUED:
10/20/2016
(301) 851-2948

17-00922_000425

USDA
al

VIA: USPS Certified Mail. Shipping: Ist October 20,
2016

Tommy Blackwell

103 High Street

Greer, SC 29651
OFFICIAL WARNING
Re: Reference number NC160021-AC
Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you violated the Horse Protection Act (15 U.S.C. § 1821 et seq.)
(HPA), as described in the attached Official Waming. Our agency, the Animal
and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing the
HPA, and other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and plant
pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may impose civil
penalties of up to $2,200, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Official Warning. Although we generally pursue penalties for this type of
violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this instance so long as

you comply, in the future. with laws that APHIS enforces.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you violate laws that APHIS
enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warming, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

What should I do if I have questions? If you have any questions concerning this
Official Warning, contact David Dissinger at (301) 851-2803 or call our main
office at (301) 851-2948.

Iam a small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding
APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?
If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health
laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small Business
Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you prefer to comment to someone outside
APHIS, contact the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsperson at
http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba.gov, or 1-888-REG-

FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s office receives comments and annually evaluates
federal agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs
of small businesses.

Sincerely,

Steven M. Bennett, Director
Investigative and Enforcement Services

OFFICIAL WARNING
Re: Reference number NC160024-AC
Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you violated the Horse Protection Act (15 U.S.C. § 1821 et seq.)
(HPA), as described in the attached Official Waming. Our agency, the Animal
and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing the
HPA, and other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and plant
pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may impose civil
penalties of up to $2,200, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Official Warning. Although we generally pursue penalties for this type of
violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this instance so long as

you comply, in the future. with laws that APHIS enforces.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you violate laws that APHIS
enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warming, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

What should I do if I have questions? If you have any questions concerning this
Official Warning, contact David Dissinger at (301) 851-2803 or call our main
office at (301) 851-2948.

Iam a small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding
APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?
If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health
laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small Business
Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you prefer to comment to someone outside
APHIS, contact the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsperson at
http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba.gov, or 1-888-REG-

FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s office receives comments and annually evaluates
federal agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs
of small businesses.

Sincerely,

Steven M. Bennett, Director
Investigative and Enforcement Services


## Enforcement Records-AWA and HPA-Sept to Oct 2016_page_236
UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE
ANIMAL AND PLANT HEALTH INSPECTION SERVICE

CASE NUMBER:
NC160024-AC

VIOLATOR:
James Brewer

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: October 9, 2015
15 U.S.C. § 1824(2)(B) Unlawful acts - Entering

The following conduct is prohibited:

(2) The (A) showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition,
of any horse which is sore, (B) entering for the purpose of showing or
exhibiting in any horse show or horse exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C)
selling, auctioning, or offering for sale, in any horse sale or auction, any horse
which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in clause (A), (B), or
(C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.

Charles Stivers was the rider who entered for the purpose of showing “Win
Baby Win” (class # 44, entry # 255) while sore, in violation of the scar rule,
and bearing a foreign substance at the North Carolina Championship Walking
Horse Show in Fletcher, North Carolina.

Date of Violation: October 9, 2015
15 U.S.C. § 1824(7) Prohibited substances

The following conduct is prohibited:
(7) The showing or exhibiting at a horse show or horse exhibition; the
selling or auctioning at a horse sale or auction; the allowing to be shown,
exhibited, or sold at a horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction;
the entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or
horse exhibition; or offering for sale at a horse sale or auction, any horse
which is wearing or bearing any equipment, device, paraphernalia, or
substance which the Secretary by regulation under section 1828 of this title
prohibits to prevent the soring of horses.
Charles Stivers entered for the purpose of showing “Win Baby Win” while
bearing a foreign substance at the North Carolina Championship Walking
Horse Show in Fletcher, North Carolina.

An Equa! Opportunity Provider and Employer Reference Number: NC160024-AC
Issuance Date: October 21. 2016
Version: Final

to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official

regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil

## Enforcement Records-AWA and HPA-Sept to Oct 2016_page_244
UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE
ANIMAL AND PLANT HEALTH INSPECTION SERVICE

CASE NUMBER:
NC160024-AC

VIOLATOR:
James Brewer

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: October 9, 2015
15 U.S.C. § 1824(2)(B) Unlawful acts - Entering

The following conduct is prohibited:

(2) The (A) showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition,
of any horse which is sore, (B) entering for the purpose of showing or
exhibiting in any horse show or horse exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C)
selling, auctioning, or offering for sale, in any horse sale or auction, any horse
which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in clause (A), (B), or
(C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.

James Brewer was the trainer who entered for the purpose of showing “Win
Baby Win” (class # 44, entry # 255) while sore, in violation of the scar rule,
and bearing a foreign substance at the North Carolina Championship Walking
Horse Show in Fletcher, North Carolina.

Date of Violation: October 9, 2015
15 U.S.C. § 1824(7) Prohibited substances

The following conduct is prohibited:
(7) The showing or exhibiting at a horse show or horse exhibition; the
selling or auctioning at a horse sale or auction; the allowing to be shown,
exhibited, or sold at a horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction;
the entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or
horse exhibition; or offering for sale at a horse sale or auction, any horse
which is wearing or bearing any equipment, device, paraphernalia, or
substance which the Secretary by regulation under section 1828 of this title
prohibits to prevent the soring of horses.
James Brewer entered for the purpose of showing “Win Baby Win” while
bearing a foreign substance at the North Carolina Championship Walking
Horse Show in Fletcher, North Carolina.

An Equa! Opportunity Provider and Employer Reference Number: NC160024-AC
Issuance Date: October 21. 2016
Version: Final

OFFICIAL WARNING
Re: Reference number NC160025-AC
Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you violated the Horse Protection Act (15 U.S.C. § 1821 et seq.)
(HPA), as described in the attached Official Waming. Our agency, the Animal
and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing the
HPA, and other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and plant
pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may impose civil
penalties of up to $2,200, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Official Warning. Although we generally pursue penalties for this type of
violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this instance so long as

you comply, in the future. with laws that APHIS enforces.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you violate laws that APHIS
enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warming, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

What should I do if I have questions? If you have any questions concerning this
Official Warning, contact David Dissinger at (301) 851-2803 or call our main
office at (301) 851-2948.

Iam a small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding
APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?
If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health
laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small Business
Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you prefer to comment to someone outside
APHIS, contact the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsperson at
http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba.gov, or 1-888-REG-

FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s office receives comments and annually evaluates
federal agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs
of small businesses.

Sincerely,

Steven M. Bennett, Director
Investigative and Enforcement Services

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: October 9, 2015
15 U.S.C. § 1824(2)(D) Unlawful acts - Allowing

The following conduct is prohibited:

(2) The (A) showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition,
of any horse which is sore, (B) entering for the purpose of showing or
exhibiting in any horse show or horse exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C)
selling, auctioning, or offering for sale, in any horse sale or auction, any horse
which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in clause (A), (B), or
(C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.

Tip King was the owner who allowed “Just Call Me Jose” (class # 46, entry #
149) to be entered for the purpose of showing, while sore and bearing a
foreign substance at the North Carolina Championship Walking Horse Show
in Fletcher, North Carolina.

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

OFFICIAL WARNING
Re: Reference number NC170006-AC
Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you violated the Horse Protection Act (15 U.S.C. § 1821 et seq.)
(HPA), as described in the attached Official Waming. Our agency, the Animal
and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing the
HPA, and other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and plant
pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may impose civil
penalties of up to $2,200, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Official Warning. Although we generally pursue penalties for this type of
violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this instance so long as

you comply, in the future. with laws that APHIS enforces.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you violate laws that APHIS
enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warming, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

What should I do if I have questions? If you have any questions concerning this
Official Warning, contact Tyrese Coleman at (301) 851-2758 or call our main
office at (301) 851-2948.

Iam a small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding
APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?
If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health
laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small Business
Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you prefer to comment to someone outside
APHIS, contact the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsperson at
http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba.gov, or 1-888-REG-

FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s office receives comments and annually evaluates
federal agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs
of small businesses.

Sincerely,

Steven M. Bennett, Director
Investigative and Enforcement Services

15 U.S.C. § 1824(2)(B) Unlawful acts. The following conduct is prohibited: (2) The (B)
entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse exhibition,

You entered the horse “E-Trade” for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in
the ETWHA Fall Classic Horse Show in White Pine, TN which was found to
be sore and in violation of the scar rule.

Date of Violation: October 17, 2015

9 C.F.R. § 11.2(c) Prohibitions conceming exhibitors. (c) Substances. All substances are
prohibited on the extremities above the hoof of any Tennessee Walking Horse or racking
horse while being shown, exhibited, or offered for sale at any horse show, horse
exhibition, or horse sale or auction, except lubricants such as glycerine, petrolatum, and
mineral oil, or mixtures thereof

the ETWHA Fall Classic Horse Show in White Pine, TN which was found to
have a black foreign substance covering its pasterns.

Date of Violation: October 17, 2015

9 C.F.R. § 11.3 Scar rule. (a) The anterior and anterior-lateral surfaces of the fore
pasterns (extensor surface) must be free of bilateral granulomas, other bilateral
pathological evidence of inflammation, and, other bilateral evidence of abuse indicative
of soring including, but not limited to, excessive loss of hair.

the ETWHA Fall Classic Horse Show in White Pine, TN which was found to
be in violation of the scar rule.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed below,
you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal Regulations:

Date of Violation: October 24, 2014
15 U.S.C. § 1824(7) Unlawful Acts

“The showing or exhibiting at a horse show or horse exhibition; the selling or
auctioning at a horse sale or auction; the allowing to be shown, exhibited, or sold
at a horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction; the entering for the
purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse exhibition; or
offering for sale at a horse sale or auction, any horse which is wearing or bearing
any equipment, device, paraphernalia, or substance which the Secretary by
regulation under Section 1828 of this title prohibits to prevent the soring of
horses.”

Date of Violation: October 24, 2014
9 C.F.R. § 11.2 (c) Prohibition concerning exhibitors — Substances

“All substances are prohibited on the extremities above the hoof of any
Tennessee Walking Horse or racking horse while being shown, exhibited, or
offered for sale at any horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction,
except lubricants such as glycerine, petrolatum, and mineral oil, or mixtures
thereof...”

David Brown allowed the entry of his horse at the show, for the purpose of
showing or exhibiting, the horse, “Jose’s Corner Market,” at the South Carolina
Walking Horse Association Championship Walking Horse Show in Clemson,
SC, which was found to be wearing a foreign substance.

OFFICIAL WARNING
Re: Reference number SC160005-AC

Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you violated the Horse Protection Act (15 U.S.C. § 1821 et seq.)
(HPA), as described in the attached Official Waming. Our agency, the Animal
and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing the
HPA, and other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and plant
pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may impose civil
penalties of up to $2,200, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Official Warning. Although we generally pursue penalties for this type of
violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this instance so long as

you comply, in the future. with laws that APHIS enforces.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you violate laws that APHIS
enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warming, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

What should I do if I have questions? If you have any questions concerning this
Official Warning, contact Edmund Grant at (301) 851-2752 or call our main
office at (301) 851-2948.

Iam a small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding
APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?
If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health
laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small Business
Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you prefer to comment to someone outside
APHIS, contact the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsperson at
http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba.gov, or 1-888-REG-

FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s office receives comments and annually evaluates
federal agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs
of small businesses.

Sincerely,

Steven M. Bennett, Director
Investigative and Enforcement Services

UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE CASE NUMBER:
ANIMAL AND PLANT HEALTH INSPECTION SERVICE SC 160007-AC

VIOLATOR:
Sam Martin

ADDRESS (Street, City, State, ZiP
Code):

Leesville, SC 29070

Date of Violation: October 24, 2014
15 U.S.C. § 1824(7) Unlawful Acts

“The showing or exhibiting at a horse show or horse exhibition; the selling or
auctioning at a horse sale or auction; the allowing to be shown, exhibited, or
sold at a horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction; the entering
for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition; or offering for sale at a horse sale or auction, any horse which is
wearing or bearing any equipment, device, paraphernalia, or substance which
the Secretary by regulation under Section 1828 of this title prohibits to prevent
the soring of horses.”

“All substances are prohibited on the extremities above the hoof of any

offered for sale at any horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction,

Sam Martin entered, for the purpose of showing or exhibiting, the horse,

OFFICIAL WARNING
Re: Reference number SC160007-AC
Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you violated the Horse Protection Act (15 U.S.C. § 1821 et seq.)
(HPA), as described in the attached Official Waming. Our agency, the Animal
and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing the
HPA, and other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and plant
pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may impose civil
penalties of up to $2,200, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Official Warning. Although we generally pursue penalties for this type of
violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this instance so long as

you comply, in the future. with laws that APHIS enforces.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you violate laws that APHIS
enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warming, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

What should I do if I have questions? If you have any questions concerning this
Official Warning, contact Edmund Grant at (301) 851-2752 or call our main
office at (301) 851-2948.

Iam a small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding
APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?
If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health
laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small Business
Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you prefer to comment to someone outside
APHIS, contact the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsperson at
http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba.gov, or 1-888-REG-

FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s office receives comments and annually evaluates
federal agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs
of small businesses.

Sincerely,

Steven M. Bennett, Director
Investigative and Enforcement Services

Tennessee Walking Horse or racking horse while being shown, exhibited, or
offered for sale at any horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction,
except lubricants such as glycerine, petrolatum, and mineral oil, or mixtures
thereof...”

Rhonda Baucom entered, for the purpose of showing or exhibiting, the horse,
“Jose’s Delightful Pusher,” at the South Carolina Walking Horse Association
Championship Walking Horse Show in Clemson, SC, which was found to be
wearing a foreign substance.

to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests

Meme Anderson
565 Bethune Highway
Bishopville, SC 29010

OFFICIAL WARNING
Re: Reference number SC160010-AC
Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you violated the Horse Protection Act (15 U.S.C. § 1821 et seq.)
(HPA), as described in the attached Official Waming. Our agency, the Animal
and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing the
HPA, and other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and plant
pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may impose civil
penalties of up to $2,200, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Official Warning. Although we generally pursue penalties for this type of
violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this instance so long as

you comply, in the future. with laws that APHIS enforces.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you violate laws that APHIS
enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warming, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

What should I do if I have questions? If you have any questions concerning this
Official Warning, contact Edmund Grant at (301) 851-2752 or call our main
office at (301) 851-2948.

Iam a small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding
APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?
If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health
laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small Business
Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you prefer to comment to someone outside
APHIS, contact the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsperson at
http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba.gov, or 1-888-REG-

FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s office receives comments and annually evaluates
federal agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs
of small businesses.

Sincerely,

Steven M. Bennett, Director
Investigative and Enforcement Services

below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: October 24, 2014
15 U.S.C. § 1824(7) Unlawful Acts

“The showing or exhibiting at a horse show or horse exhibition; the selling or
auctioning at a horse sale or auction; the allowing to be shown, exhibited, or
sold at a horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction; the entering
for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition; or offering for sale at a horse sale or auction, any horse which is
wearing or bearing any equipment, device, paraphernalia, or substance which
the Secretary by regulation under Section 1828 of this title prohibits to prevent

9 C.F.R. § 11.2 (c) Prohibition concerning exhibitors — Substances

“All substances are prohibited on the extremities above the hoof of any
Tennessee Walking Horse or racking horse while being shown, exhibited, or
offered for sale at any horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction,
except lubricants such as glycerine, petrolatum, and mineral oil, or mixtures
thereof...”

Meme Anderson entered, for the purpose of showing or exhibiting, the horse,
“Dollar on Fire,” at the South Carolina Walking Horse Association

Championship Walking Horse Show in Clemson, SC, which was found to be
wearing a foreign substance.

and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing the
HPA, and other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and plant
pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may impose civil
penalties of up to $2,200, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Official Warning. Although we generally pursue penalties for this type of
violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this instance so long as

you comply, in the future. with laws that APHIS enforces.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you violate laws that APHIS
enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warming, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s office recetves comments and annually evaluates
federal agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs
of small businesses.

Steven M. Bennett, Director

UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE
ANIMAL AND PLANT HEALTH INSPECTION SERVICE

CASE NUMBER:

VIOLATOR:
Danny Kistler

ADDRESS (Street, City, State, ZiP
Code):

Stateville, NC 28625

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: October 24, 2014
15 U.S.C. § 1824(7) Unlawful Acts

“The showing or exhibiting at a horse show or horse exhibition; the selling or
auctioning at a horse sale or auction; the allowing to be shown, exhibited, or
sold at a horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction; the entering
for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition; or offering for sale at a horse sale or auction, any horse which is
wearing or bearing any equipment, device, paraphernalia, or substance which
the Secretary by regulation under Section 1828 of this title prohibits to prevent
the soring of horses.”

Date of Violation: October 24, 2014
9 C.F.R. § 11.2 (c) Prohibition concerning exhibitors — Substances

“All substances are prohibited on the extremities above the hoof of any
Tennessee Walking Horse or racking horse while being shown, exhibited, or
offered for sale at any horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction,
except lubricants such as glycerine, petrolatum, and mineral oil, or mixtures
thereof...”

Danny Kistler entered, for the purpose of showing or exhibiting, the horse,
“Beach Babe,” at the South Carolina Walking Horse Association
Championship Walking Horse Show in Clemson, SC, which was found to be
wearing a foreign substance.

Reference Number: SC160012-
An Equa! Opportunity Provider and Employer AC

Larry Mesimer
