OFFICIAL WARNING
Re: Reference number SC160012-AC
Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you violated the Horse Protection Act (15 U.S.C. § 1821 et seq.)
(HPA), as described in the attached Official Waming. Our agency, the Animal
and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing the
HPA, and other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and plant
pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may impose civil
penalties of up to $2,200, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Official Warning. Although we generally pursue penalties for this type of
violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this instance so long as

you comply, in the future. with laws that APHIS enforces.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you violate laws that APHIS
enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warming, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

What should I do if I have questions? If you have any questions concerning this
Official Warning, contact Edmund Grant at (301) 851-2752 or call our main
office at (301) 851-2948.

Iam a small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding
APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?
If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health
laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small Business
Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you prefer to comment to someone outside
APHIS, contact the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsperson at
http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba.gov, or 1-888-REG-

FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s office receives comments and annually evaluates
federal agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs
of small businesses.

Sincerely,

Steven M. Bennett, Director
Investigative and Enforcement Services

http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba.gov, or 1-888-REG-

FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s office receives comments and annually evaluates
federal agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs
of small businesses.

Sincerely,

Steven M. Bennett, Director
Investigative and Enforcement Services

Regulations:

15 U.S.C. § 1824(7) Unlawful Acts

“The showing or exhibiting at a horse show or horse exhibition; the selling or
auctioning at a horse sale or auction; the allowing to be shown, exhibited, or
sold at a horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction; the entering
for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition; or offering for sale at a horse sale or auction, any horse which is

OFFICIAL WARNING
Re: Reference number SC160015-AC
Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you violated the Horse Protection Act (15 U.S.C. § 1821 et seq.)
(HPA), as described in the attached Official Waming. Our agency, the Animal
and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing the
HPA, and other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and plant
pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may impose civil
penalties of up to $2,200, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Official Warning. Although we generally pursue penalties for this type of
violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this instance so long as

you comply, in the future. with laws that APHIS enforces.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you violate laws that APHIS
enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warming, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

What should I do if I have questions? If you have any questions concerning this
Official Warning, contact Edmund Grant at (301) 851-2752 or call our main
office at (301) 851-2948.

Iam a small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding
APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?
If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health
laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small Business
Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you prefer to comment to someone outside
APHIS, contact the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsperson at
http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba.gov, or 1-888-REG-

FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s office receives comments and annually evaluates
federal agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs
of small businesses.

Sincerely,

Steven M. Bennett, Director
Investigative and Enforcement Services

pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

Official Warning. Although we generally pursue penalties for this type of
violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this instance so long as

you comply, in the future. with laws that APHIS enforces.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you violate laws that APHIS
enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warming, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba.gov, or 1-888-REG-

SC160015-AC

Steve Gamble

ADDRESS (Street, City, State, ZiP
Code):

New Zion, SC 29111

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: October 25, 2014
15 U.S.C. § 1824(7) Unlawful Acts

“The showing or exhibiting at a horse show or horse exhibition; the selling or
auctioning at a horse sale or auction; the allowing to be shown, exhibited, or
sold at a horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction; the entering
for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition; or offering for sale at a horse sale or auction, any horse which is
wearing or bearing any equipment, device, paraphernalia, or substance which
the Secretary by regulation under Section 1828 of this title prohibits to prevent
the soring of horses.”

Date of Violation: October 25, 2014
9 C.F.R. § 11.2(c) Prohibition concerning exhibitors — Substances

“All substances are prohibited on the extremities above the hoof of any
Tennessee Walking Horse or racking horse while being shown, exhibited, or
offered for sale at any horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction,
except lubricants such as glycerine, petrolatum, and mineral oil, or mixtures
thereof...”

Steve Gamble allowed the entry of his horse at the show, for the purpose of

showing or exhibiting, the horse, “Coin’s Mega Dollar,” at the South Carolina
Walking Horse Association Championship Walking Horse Show in Clemson,
SC, which was found to be wearing a foreign substance.

OFFICIAL WARNING
Re: Reference number SC160016-AC
Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you violated the Horse Protection Act (15 U.S.C. § 1821 et seq.)
(HPA), as described in the attached Official Waming. Our agency, the Animal
and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing the
HPA, and other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and plant
pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may impose civil
penalties of up to $2,200, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Official Warning. Although we generally pursue penalties for this type of
violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this instance so long as

you comply, in the future. with laws that APHIS enforces.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you violate laws that APHIS
enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warming, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

What should I do if I have questions? If you have any questions concerning this
Official Warning, contact Edmund Grant at (301) 851-2752 or call our main
office at (301) 851-2948.

Iam a small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding
APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?
If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health
laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small Business
Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you prefer to comment to someone outside
APHIS, contact the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsperson at
http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba.gov, or 1-888-REG-

FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s office receives comments and annually evaluates
federal agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs
of small businesses.

Sincerely,

Steven M. Bennett, Director
Investigative and Enforcement Services

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE CASE NUMBER:
ANIMAL AND PLANT HEALTH INSPECTION SERVICE SC160018-AC

VIOLATOR:
Emma Lee Cannon

ADDRESS (Street, City, State, ZiP
Code):

Sumter, Sc 29150

Date of Violation: October 25, 2014
15 U.S.C. § 1824(7) Unlawful Acts

“The showing or exhibiting at a horse show or horse exhibition; the selling or
auctioning at a horse sale or auction; the allowing to be shown, exhibited, or
sold at a horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction; the entering
for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition; or offering for sale at a horse sale or auction, any horse which is
wearing or bearing any equipment, device, paraphernalia, or substance which
the Secretary by regulation under Section 1828 of this title prohibits to prevent
the soring of horses.”

Date of Violation: October 25, 2014
9 C.F.R. § 11.2 (c) Prohibition concerning exhibitors — Substances

“All substances are prohibited on the extremities above the hoof of any
Tennessee Walking Horse or racking horse while being shown, exhibited, or
offered for sale at any horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction,
except lubricants such as glycerine, petrolatum, and mineral oil, or mixtures
thereof...”

Emma Lee Cannon entered, for the purpose of showing or exhibiting, the
horse, “Major Title,” at the South Carolina Walking Horse Association
Championship Walking Horse Show in Clemson, SC, which was found to be
wearing a foreign substance.

Reference Number: SC160018-

An Equa! Opportunity Provider and Employer AC

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

Sam Martin

445 Marcellus Road

Leesville, SC 29070
OFFICIAL WARNING
Re: Reference number SC160018-AC
Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you violated the Horse Protection Act (15 U.S.C. § 1821 et seq.)
(HPA), as described in the attached Official Waming. Our agency, the Animal
and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing the
HPA, and other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and plant
pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may impose civil
penalties of up to $2,200, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Official Warning. Although we generally pursue penalties for this type of
violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this instance so long as

you comply, in the future. with laws that APHIS enforces.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you violate laws that APHIS
enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warming, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

What should I do if I have questions? If you have any questions concerning this
Official Warning, contact Edmund Grant at (301) 851-2752 or call our main
office at (301) 851-2948.

Iam a small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding
APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?
If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health
laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small Business
Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you prefer to comment to someone outside
APHIS, contact the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsperson at
http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba.gov, or 1-888-REG-

FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s office receives comments and annually evaluates
federal agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs
of small businesses.

Sincerely,

Steven M. Bennett, Director
Investigative and Enforcement Services

15 U.S.C. § 1824(7) Unlawful Acts

“The showing or exhibiting at a horse show or horse exhibition; the selling or
auctioning at a horse sale or auction; the allowing to be shown, exhibited, or
sold at a horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction; the entering
for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse

## Enforcement Records-AWA and HPA-Sept to Oct 2016_page_381
UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE
ANIMAL AND PLANT HEALTH INSPECTION SERVICE

CASE NUMBER:
SC160020-AC

VIOLATOR:
Chad Adams

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: October 25, 2014
15 U.S.C. § 1824(7) Unlawful Acts

“The showing or exhibiting at a horse show or horse exhibition; the selling or
auctioning at a horse sale or auction; the allowing to be shown, exhibited, or
sold at a horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction; the entering
for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition; or offering for sale at a horse sale or auction, any horse which is
wearing or bearing any equipment, device, paraphernalia, or substance which
the Secretary by regulation under Section 1828 of this title prohibits to prevent
the soring of horses.”

Date of Violation: October 25, 2014
9 C.F.R. § 11.2(c) Prohibition conceming exhibitors — Substances

“All substances are prohibited on the extremities above the hoof of any
Tennessee Walking Horse or racking horse while being shown, exhibited, or
offered for sale at any horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction,
except lubricants such as glycerine, petrolatum, and mineral oil, or mixtures
thereof...”

Chad Adams entered, for the purpose of showing or exhibiting, the horse,
“Romam on parole,” at the South Carolina Walking Horse Association
Championship Walking Horse Show in Clemson, SC, which was found to be
wearing a foreign substance.

An Equal Opportunity Provider and Employer Reference Number: SC160020-AC
Issuance Date: October 19. 2016
Version: Final

## Enforcement Records-AWA and HPA-Sept to Oct 2016_page_382
USDA
Ela!

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

APHIS OFFICIAL (ame): OFFICE ADDRESS:

Riverdale, MD 20737

Sam Martin

445 Marcellus Road

Leesville, SC 29070
OFFICIAL WARNING
Re: Reference number SC160021-AC
Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you violated the Horse Protection Act (15 U.S.C. § 1821 et seq.)
(HPA), as described in the attached Official Waming. Our agency, the Animal
and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing the
HPA, and other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and plant
pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may impose civil
penalties of up to $2,200, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Official Warning. Although we generally pursue penalties for this type of
violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this instance so long as

you comply, in the future. with laws that APHIS enforces.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you violate laws that APHIS
enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warming, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

What should I do if I have questions? If you have any questions concerning this
Official Warning, contact Edmund Grant at (301) 851-2752 or call our main
office at (301) 851-2948.

Iam a small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding
APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?
If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health
laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small Business
Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you prefer to comment to someone outside
APHIS, contact the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsperson at
http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba.gov, or 1-888-REG-

FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s office receives comments and annually evaluates
federal agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs
of small businesses.

Sincerely,

Steven M. Bennett, Director
Investigative and Enforcement Services

OFFICIAL WARNING
Re: Reference number SC160021-AC
Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you violated the Horse Protection Act (15 U.S.C. § 1821 et seq.)
(HPA), as described in the attached Official Waming. Our agency, the Animal
and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing the
HPA, and other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and plant
pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may impose civil
penalties of up to $2,200, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Official Warning. Although we generally pursue penalties for this type of
violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this instance so long as

you comply, in the future. with laws that APHIS enforces.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you violate laws that APHIS
enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warming, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

What should I do if I have questions? If you have any questions concerning this
Official Warning, contact Edmund Grant at (301) 851-2752 or call our main
office at (301) 851-2948.

Iam a small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding
APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?
If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health
laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small Business
Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you prefer to comment to someone outside
APHIS, contact the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsperson at
http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba.gov, or 1-888-REG-

FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s office receives comments and annually evaluates
federal agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs
of small businesses.

Sincerely,

Steven M. Bennett, Director
Investigative and Enforcement Services

Leesville, SC 29070

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: October 25, 2014
15 U.S.C. § 1824(7) Unlawful Acts

“The showing or exhibiting at a horse show or horse exhibition; the selling or
auctioning at a horse sale or auction; the allowing to be shown, exhibited, or
sold at a horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction; the entering
for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition; or offering for sale at a horse sale or auction, any horse which is

thereof...”

Stephanie Rose Martin allowed the entry of her horse at the show, for the
purpose of showing or exhibiting, the horse, “Truck Yeah,” at the South
Carolina Walking Horse Association Championship Walking Horse Show in
Clemson, SC, which was found to be wearing a foreign substance.

you comply, in the future. with laws that APHIS enforces.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you violate laws that APHIS
enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warning, in addition to any

office at (301) 851-2948.

Zam a small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding
APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?
If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health
laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small Business
Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you prefer to comment to someone outside
APHIS, contact the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsperson at
http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba.gov, or 1-888-REG-

FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s office receives comments and annually evaluates
federal agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs
of small businesses.

Sincerely,

Voth et

Steven M. Bennett, Director

below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: October 25, 2014
15 U.S.C. § 1824(7) Unlawful Acts

“The showing or exhibiting at a horse show or horse exhibition; the selling or
auctioning at a horse sale or auction; the allowing to be shown, exhibited, or
sold at a horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction; the entering
for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition; or offering for sale at a horse sale or auction, any horse which is

Tennessee Walking Horse or racking horse while being shown, exhibited, or
offered for sale at any horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction,
except lubricants such as glycerine, petrolatum, and mineral oil, or mixtures
thereof...”

showing or exhibiting, the horse, “He’s Black as Night,” at the South Carolina
Walking Horse Association Championship Walking Horse Show in Clemson,
SC, which was found to be wearing a foreign substance.

USDA

Sa
ME unites states Department of Agriculture

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warming or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

2016

Sam Martin

445 Marcellus Road

Leesville, SC 29070
OFFICIAL WARNING
Re: Reference number SC160023-AC
Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you violated the Horse Protection Act (15 U.S.C. § 1821 et seq.)
(HPA), as described in the attached Official Warning. Our agency, the Animal
and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing the
HPA, and other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and plant
pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may impose civil
penalties of up to $2,200, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Official Warning. Although we generally pursue penalties for this type of
violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this instance so long as

you comply, in the future. with laws that APHIS enforces.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you violate laws that APHIS
enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warning, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

What should I do if I have questions? If you have any questions concerning this
Official Warning, contact Edmund Grant at (301) 851-2752 or call our main
office at (301) 851-2948.

Zam a small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding
APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?
If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health
laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small Business
Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you prefer to comment to someone outside
APHIS, contact the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsperson at
http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba.gov, or 1-888-REG-

FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s office receives comments and annually evaluates
federal agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs
of small businesses.

Sincerely,

Voth et

Steven M. Bennett, Director

## Enforcement Records-AWA and HPA-Sept to Oct 2016_page_416
USDA

Sa
ME unites states Department of Agriculture

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warming or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

OFFICIAL WARNING
Re: Reference number SC160025-AC
Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you violated the Horse Protection Act (15 U.S.C. § 1821 et seq.)
(HPA), as described in the attached Official Warning. Our agency, the Animal
and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing the
HPA, and other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and plant
pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may impose civil
penalties of up to $2,200, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Official Warning. Although we generally pursue penalties for this type of
violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this instance so long as

you comply, in the future. with laws that APHIS enforces.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you violate laws that APHIS
enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warning, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

What should I do if I have questions? If you have any questions concerning this
Official Warning, contact Edmund Grant at (301) 851-2752 or call our main
office at (301) 851-2948.

Zam a small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding
APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?
If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health
laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small Business
Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you prefer to comment to someone outside
APHIS, contact the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsperson at
http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba.gov, or 1-888-REG-

FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s office receives comments and annually evaluates
federal agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs
of small businesses.

Sincerely,

Voth et

Steven M. Bennett, Director

Wartrace, TN 37183

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: October 25, 2014
15 U.S.C. § 1824(7) Unlawful Acts

“The showing or exhibiting at a horse show or horse exhibition; the selling or
auctioning at a horse sale or auction; the allowing to be shown, exhibited, or
sold at a horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction; the entering
for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse

exhibition; or offering for sale at a horse sale or auction, any horse which is
wearing or bearing any equipment, device, paraphernalia, or substance which
the Secretary by regulation under Section 1828 of this title prohibits to prevent
the soring of horses.”

Date of Violation: October 25, 2014
9 C.F.R. § 11.2 (c) Prohibition concerning exhibitors — Substances

“All substances are prohibited on the extremities above the hoof of any
Tennessee Walking Horse or racking horse while being shown, exhibited, or
offered for sale at any horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction,
except lubricants such as glycerine, petrolatum, and mineral oil, or mixtures
thereof...”

Chad Way entered, for the purpose of showing or exhibiting, the horse, “Strait
Line Cash,” at the South Carolina Walking Horse Association Championship
Walking Horse Show in Clemson, SC, which was found to be wearing a
foreign substance.

ME unites states Department of Agriculture

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warming or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE CASE NUMBER:
ANIMAL AND PLANT HEALTH INSPECTION SERVICE SC160026-AC

yD VIOLATOR:
ORPRCIAL) iG

VIOLATION OF FEDERAL REGULATIONS KODRESS (Stree, CW, Sie, ZP
lee» Wages — 4 le):

Leesville, SC 29070

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: October 25, 2014
15 U.S.C. § 1824(7) Unlawful Acts

“The showing or exhibiting at a horse show or horse exhibition; the selling or
auctioning at a horse sale or auction; the allowing to be shown, exhibited, or
sold at a horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction; the entering
for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse

exhibition; or offering for sale at a horse sale or auction, any horse which is
wearing or bearing any equipment, device, paraphernalia, or substance which
the Secretary by regulation under Section 1828 of this title prohibits to prevent
the soring of horses.”

Date of Violation: October 25, 2014
9 C.F.R. § 11.2 (c) Prohibition concerning exhibitors — Substances

“All substances are prohibited on the extremities above the hoof of any
Tennessee Walking Horse or racking horse while being shown, exhibited, or
offered for sale at any horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction,
except lubricants such as glycerine, petrolatum, and mineral oil, or mixtures
thereof...”

Sam Martin entered, for the purpose of showing or exhibiting, the horse, “Jose
Today,” at the South Carolina Walking Horse Association Championship
Walking Horse Show in Clemson, SC, which was found to be wearing a
foreign substance.

Reference Number: SC160026-
An Equa! Opportunity Provider and Employer AC

Issuance Date: October 19. 2016
Version: Final

17-00922_000627


## Enforcement Records-AWA and HPA-Sept to Oct 2016_page_436
USDA

Sa
ME unites states Department of Agriculture

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warming or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

APHIS OFFICIAL (Name): OFFICE ADDRESS:
Steven M. Bennett 4700 River Road, Unit 85
Riverdale, MD 20737
APHIS OFFICIAL (Title): DATE ISSUED: cig
i igati i 10/19/2016 :

aI United States Department of Agriculture

VIA: USPS Certified Mail. Shipping: Ist October 19,
2016

Beulah Essary

2856 Shiloh Circle

Strawberry plains, TN 37871
OFFICIAL WARNING
Re: Reference number SC160027-AC
Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you violated the Horse Protection Act (15 U.S.C. § 1821 et seq.)
(HPA), as described in the attached Official Warning. Our agency, the Animal
and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing the
HPA, and other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and plant
pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may impose civil
penalties of up to $2,200, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Official Warning. Although we generally pursue penalties for this type of
violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this instance so long as

you comply, in the future. with laws that APHIS enforces.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you violate laws that APHIS
enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warning, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

What should I do if I have questions? If you have any questions concerning this
Official Warning, contact Edmund Grant at (301) 851-2752 or call our main
office at (301) 851-2948.

Zam a small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding
APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?
If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health
laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small Business
Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you prefer to comment to someone outside
APHIS, contact the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsperson at
http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba.gov, or 1-888-REG-

FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s office receives comments and annually evaluates
federal agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs
of small businesses.

Sincerely,

Voth et

Steven M. Bennett, Director

enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil

USDA

Sa
ME unites states Department of Agriculture

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warming or

VIA: USPS Certified Mail. Shipping: Ist October 28,
2016

Don Broome

PO Box 8

Rogersville, TN 37857

OFFICIAL WARNING
NOTICE OF ALLEGED VIOLATION

Re: Reference number TN160014-AC
Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you failed to comply with the Horse Protection Act (15 U.S.C. §
1821 et seq.) (HPA), and its implementing regulations, as described in the
attached Official Warning. Our agency, the Animal and Plant Health Inspection
Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing the HPA, and regulations and other
agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests and
diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may pursue civil
penalties of up to $2,200, or other sanctions, for each alleged violation described
in this Official Warning. Although we have authority to pursue penalties for this
type of alleged violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this

instance so long as you comply. in the future. with the HPA and regulations.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you fail to comply in the
future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil penalties for the
alleged violations described in this Official Warning, in addition to any penalties
we may pursue for any future violations.

What should I do if I have questions? If you have any questions concerning this
Official Warning, contact David Dissinger at (301) 851-2803 or call our main
office at (301) 851-2948.

Iam a small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding
APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?
If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health
laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small Business
Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you prefer to comment to someone outside
APHIS, contact the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsperson at
http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba.gov, or 1-888-REG-

FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s office receives comments and annually evaluates
federal agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs
of small businesses.

Sincerely,

Steven M. Bennett, Director
Investigative and Enforcement Services

NOTICE OF ALLEGED VIOLATION

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following alleged violation(s) of Federal
laws:

Date of Alleged Violation: August 1, 2015
15 U.S.C. § 1824(2)(D) Unlawful acts - Allowing

UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE CASE NUMBER:
ANIMAL AND PLANT HEALTH INSPECTION SERVICE T™N160014-AC
ALLEGED VIOLATOR:

Don Broome

ADDRESS (City, State, Z/P Code):

OFFICIAL.WARNING Rogersville, TN 37857

The following conduct is prohibited:

(2) The (A) showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition,
of any horse which is sore, (B) entering for the purpose of showing or
exhibiting in any horse show or horse exhibition, any horse which ts sore, (C)
selling, auctioning, or offering for sale, in any horse sale or auction, any horse
which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in clause (A), (B), or
(C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.

Don Broome allowed, “The Coach’s Son” (entry # 437, class # 13) to be
entered for the purpose of showing at the 109th Anniversary Wartrace Horse
Show in Wartrace, Tennessee where the horse was found sore during a pre-
show inspection.

## Enforcement Records-AWA and HPA-Sept to Oct 2016_page_451
USDA
Ela

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) published federal
regulations to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and
plant pests and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and
costly impacts that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with
an Official Warming for the alleged violation(s) described above. This Official
Warning is not to be construed as a final agency action, or as an adjudicated finding of
a violation. If APHIS obtains evidence of any future violation of these federal
regulations, APHIS may pursue civil penalties, criminal prosecution, or other
sanctions for this alleged violation(s) and for any future violation(s). If you have any
questions concerning this Official Warning or alleged violation(s), please contact the
APHIS official listed in this notice.

APHIS OFFICIAL (Name): OFFICE ADDRESS:
Steven M. Bennett 4700 River Road, Unit 85

Riverdale, MD 20737

APHIS OFFICIAL (Title): DATE ISSUED: ao
Director, Investigative and Enforcement Services 10/28/2016 apt REL SOER

1821 et seq.) (HPA), and its implementing regulations, as described in the
attached Official Warning. Our agency, the Animal and Plant Health Inspection
Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing the HPA, and regulations and other
agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests and
diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may pursue civil
penalties of up to $2,200, or other sanctions, for each alleged violation described
in this Official Warning. Although we have authority to pursue penalties for this
type of alleged violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this

instance so long as you comply. in the future. with the HPA and regulations.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you fail to comply in the
future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil penalties for the
alleged violations described in this Official Warning, in addition to any penalties
we may pursue for any future violations.

What should I do if I have questions? If you have any questions concerning this
Official Warning, contact David Dissinger at (301) 851-2803 or call our main
office at (301) 851-2948.

Iam a small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding
APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?
If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health
laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small Business
Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you prefer to comment to someone outside
APHIS, contact the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsperson at
http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba.gov, or 1-888-REG-

FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s office receives comments and annually evaluates
federal agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs
of small businesses.

Sincerely,

Steven M. Bennett, Director
Investigative and Enforcement Services

OFFICIAL WARNING
Re: Reference number TN160208-AC
Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you violated the Horse Protection Act (15 U.S.C. § 1821 et seq.)
(HPA), as described in the attached Official Warning. Our agency, the Animal
and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing the
HPA, and other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and plant
pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may impose civil
penalties of up to $2,200, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Official Warning. Although we generally pursue penalties for this type of
violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this instance so long as

you comply, in the future. with laws that APHIS enforces.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you violate laws that APHIS
enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warning, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

What should I do if I have questions? If you have any questions concerning this
Official Warning, contact David Dissinger at (301) 851-2803 or call our main
office at (301) 851-2948.

Zam a small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding
APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?
If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health
laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small Business
Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you prefer to comment to someone outside
APHIS, contact the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsperson at
http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba.gov, or 1-888-REG-

FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s office receives comments and annually evaluates
federal agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs
of small businesses.

Sincerely,

to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests

We believe that you violated the Horse Protection Act (15 U.S.C. § 1821 et seq.)
(HPA), as described in the attached Official Warning. Our agency, the Animal
and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing the
HPA, and other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and plant
pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may impose civil
penalties of up to $2,200, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Official Warning. Although we generally pursue penalties for this type of
violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this instance so long as

you comply, in the future. with laws that APHIS enforces.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you violate laws that APHIS
enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warning, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

What should I do if I have questions? If you have any questions concerning this
Official Warning, contact David Dissinger at (301) 851-2803 or call our main
office at (301) 851-2948.

Zam a small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding
APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?
If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health
laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small Business
Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you prefer to comment to someone outside
APHIS, contact the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsperson at
http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba.gov, or 1-888-REG-

FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s office receives comments and annually evaluates
federal agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs
of small businesses.

Sincerely,

Vt et

Steven M. Bennett, Acting Director

Official Warning, contact Kelly Ferrell at (301) 851-2755 or call our main office
at (301) 851-2948.

OFFICIAL WARNING
Re: Reference number AL160046-AC
Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you violated the Horse Protection Act (15 U.S.C. § 1821 et seq.)
(HPA), as described in the attached Official Waming. Our agency, the Animal
and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing the
HPA, and other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and plant
pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may impose civil
penalties of up to $2,200, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Official Warning. Although we generally pursue penalties for this type of
violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this instance so long as

you comply, in the future. with laws that APHIS enforces.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you violate laws that APHIS
enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warming, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

What should I do if I have questions? If you have any questions concerning this
Official Warning, contact Kelly Ferrell at (301) 851-2755 or call our main office
at (301) 851-2948.

Iam a small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding
APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?
If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health
laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small Business
Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you prefer to comment to someone outside
APHIS, contact the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsperson at
http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba.gov, or 1-888-REG-

FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s office receives comments and annually evaluates
federal agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs
of small businesses.

Sincerely,

Steven M. Bennett, Director
Investigative and Enforcement Services


## Enforcement Records-AWA and HPA-Sept to Oct 2016_page_490
UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE
ANIMAL AND PLANT HEALTH INSPECTION SERVICE

CASE NUMBER:
AL160046-AC

VIOLATOR:
Ann M. Amold

ADDRESS (Street, City, State, ZiP
Code):

Hanceville, AL 35077

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: September 25, 2015

15 U.S.C. § 1824(2)(D) Unlawful Acts. The following conduct is prohibited: The (A)
showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition, of any horse which is sore,
(B) entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C) selling, auctioning or offering for sale, in any
horse sale or auction, any horse which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in
clause (A), (B), or (C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.”

9 C.F.R. § 11.3 Horses subject to this rule that do not meet the following scar rule
criteria shall be considered to be “sore” and are subject to all prohibitions of section 5 of
the Act.

You allowed your horse “Barnburner Prince of Tide”, (entry number 933,

class number 149) to be shown in the 44th Annual Racking Horse Breeders
Association of America, 2015 World Celebration in Decatur, AL where the
horse was found sore and in violation of the scar rule.

of any horse which is sore, (B) entering for the purpose of showing or
exhibiting in any horse show or horse exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C)

(2) The (A) showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition,
of any horse which is sore, (B) entering for the purpose of showing or
exhibiting in any horse show or horse exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C)
selling, auctioning, or offering for sale, in any horse sale or auction, any horse
which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in clause (A), (B), or
(C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.

Richard Williams was the trainer who entered for the purpose of showing,
“Tm Jailbait” (class # 155, entry # 745) while in violation of the scar rule at
the 44th RHBAA Celebration horse show in Decatur, Alabama.

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

4700 River Road, Unit 85
Riverdale, MD 20737

violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this instance so long as

Danny Odum

16862 Boundary Road

Creal Springs, IL 62922
OFFICIAL WARNING
Re: Reference number AL160052-AC
Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you violated the Horse Protection Act (15 U.S.C. § 1821 et seq.)
(HPA), as described in the attached Official Warning. Our agency, the Animal
and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing the
HPA, and other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and plant
pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may impose civil
penalties of up to $2,200, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Official Warning. Although we generally pursue penalties for this type of
violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this instance so long as

you comply, in the future. with laws that APHIS enforces.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you violate laws that APHIS
enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warning, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

What should I do if I have questions? If you have any questions concerning this
Official Warning, contact David Dissinger at (301) 851-2803 or call our main
office at (301) 851-2948.

Zam a small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding
APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?
If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health
laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small Business
Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you prefer to comment to someone outside
APHIS, contact the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsperson at
http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba.gov, or 1-888-REG-

FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s office receives comments and annually evaluates
federal agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs
of small businesses.

Sincerely,

Voth et

Steven M. Bennett, Director

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: September 26, 2015
15 U.S.C. § 1824(2)(B) Unlawful acts - Entering

The following conduct is prohibited:

(2) The (A) showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition,
of any horse which is sore, (B) entering for the purpose of showing or
exhibiting in any horse show or horse exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C)
selling, auctioning, or offering for sale, in any horse sale or auction, any horse
which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in clause (A), (B), or
(C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.

Danny Odum was the trainer who entered for the purpose of showing, “Wow
Factor” (class # 161, entry # 252) while sore at the 44th RHBAA Celebration
horse show in Decatur, Alabama.

## Enforcement Records-AWA and HPA-Sept to Oct 2016_page_519
USDA

Sa
ME unites states Department of Agriculture

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warming or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

APHIS OFFICIAL (Name): OFFICE ADDRESS:
Steven M. Bennett 4700 River Road, Unit 85
Riverdale, MD 20737

OFFICIAL WARNING
Re: Reference number AL160053-AC
Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you violated the Horse Protection Act (15 U.S.C. § 1821 et seq.)
(HPA), as described in the attached Official Waming. Our agency, the Animal
and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing the
HPA, and other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and plant
pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may impose civil
penalties of up to $2,200, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Official Warning. Although we generally pursue penalties for this type of
violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this instance so long as

you comply, in the future. with laws that APHIS enforces.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you violate laws that APHIS
enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warming, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

What should I do if I have questions? If you have any questions concerning this
Official Warning, contact David Dissinger at (301) 851-2803 or call our main
office at (301) 851-2948.

Iam a small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding
APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?
If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health
laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small Business
Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you prefer to comment to someone outside
APHIS, contact the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsperson at
http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba.gov, or 1-888-REG-

FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s office receives comments and annually evaluates
federal agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs
of small businesses.

Sincerely,

Steven M. Bennett, Director
Investigative and Enforcement Services

penalties for the violations described in this Official Warming, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

What should I do if I have questions? If you have any questions concerning this
Official Warning, contact David Dissinger at (301) 851-2803 or call our main
office at (301) 851-2948.

Iam a small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding
APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?
If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health
laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small Business
Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you prefer to comment to someone outside
APHIS, contact the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsperson at
http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba.gov, or 1-888-REG-

FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s office receives comments and annually evaluates
federal agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs
of small businesses.

Steven M. Bennett, Director

violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this instance so long as

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: September 26, 2015
15 U.S.C. § 1824(2)(D) Unlawful act - Allowing

The following conduct is prohibited:

(2) The (A) showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition, of
any horse which is sore, (B) entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting
in any horse show or horse exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C) selling,
auctioning, or offering for sale, in any horse sale or auction, any horse which
is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in clause (A), (B), or (C)
respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.

Nicole Garon Rehkemper was the owner who allowed “The Legacy” (class #
160, entry # 722) to be entered for the purpose of showing while sore, in
violation of the scar rule, and bearing a foreign substance on it’s right front
pastern at the 44th RHBAA World Celebration in Decatur, Alabama.

OFFICIAL WARNING
Re: Reference number AL160057-AC
Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you violated the Horse Protection Act (15 U.S.C. § 1821 et seq.)
(HPA), as described in the attached Official Warning. Our agency, the Animal
and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing the
HPA, and other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and plant
pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may impose civil
penalties of up to $2,200, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Official Warning. Although we generally pursue penalties for this type of
violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this instance so long as

you comply, in the future. with laws that APHIS enforces.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you violate laws that APHIS
enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warning, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

What should I do if I have questions? If you have any questions concerning this
Official Warning, contact David Dissinger at (301) 851-2803 or call our main
office at (301) 851-2948.

Zam a small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding
APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?
If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health
laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small Business
Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you prefer to comment to someone outside
APHIS, contact the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsperson at
http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba.gov, or 1-888-REG-

FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s office receives comments and annually evaluates
federal agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs
of small businesses.

Sincerely,

Voth et

Steven M. Bennett, Director

Victor Chemerisov

OFFICIAL WARNING
NOTICE OF ALLEGED VIOLATION

Re: Reference number FL150063-AC
Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you failed to comply with the Animal Welfare Act (7 U.S.C. §
2131 et seq.) (AWA), and its implementing regulations, as described in the
attached Official Warning. Our agency, the Animal and Plant Health Inspection
Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing the AWA, and regulations and
other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests and
diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may pursue civil
penalties of up to $10,000, or other sanctions, for each alleged violation described
in this Official Warning. Although we have authority to pursue penalties for this
type of alleged violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this

instance so long as you comply. in the future. with the AWA and regulations.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you fail to comply in the
future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil penalties for the
alleged violations described in this Official Warning, in addition to any penalties
we may pursue for any future violations.

What should I do if I have questions? If you have any questions concerning this
Official Warning, contact Roxanne Folk at (301) 851-2736 or call our main office
at (301) 851-2948.

Iam a small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding
APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?
If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health
laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small Business
Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you prefer to comment to someone outside
APHIS, contact the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsperson at
http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba.gov, or 1-888-REG-

FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s office receives comments and annually evaluates
federal agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs
of small businesses.

Sincerely,

Steven M. Bennett, Director
Investigative and Enforcement Services

Victor Chemerisov

ADDRESS (City, State, Z/P Code):

OFFICIAL WARNING Hollywood, FL 33019

NOTICE OF ALLEGED VIOLATION

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following alleged violation(s) of Federal
laws:

Date of Alleged Violation: On or about February 21, 2014 through September 17,
2014

9 C.F.R. § 2.1(a)(1) Requirements and application. Any person operating or tending to
operate as a dealer, exhibitor, or operator of an auction sale, except persons who are
exempted from the licensing requirements under paragraph (a)(3) of this section, must
have a valid license. A person must be 18 years of age or older to obtain a license.

You conducted regulated activity without a valid USDA license. You acted as
a dealer when you sold at least 15 French and English Bulldogs sight unseen
to several individuals throughout the United States.

regulations to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and
plant pests and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and
costly impacts that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with
an Official Warming for the alleged violation(s) described above. This Official
Warning is not to be construed as a final agency action, or as an adjudicated finding of
a violation. If APHIS obtains evidence of any future violation of these federal
regulations, APHIS may pursue civil penalties, criminal prosecution, or other
sanctions for this alleged violation(s) and for any future violation(s). If you have any
questions concerning this Official Warning or alleged violation(s), please contact the

in ew hy Hephzibah, GA 30815

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: On or about September 6, 2014

9 C.F.R. § 2.1(a)(1) Requirements and application.

(a)(1) Any person operating or intending to operate as a dealer, exhibitor, or operator of
an auction sale, except persons who are exempted from the licensing requirements under
paragraph(a)(3) of this section, must have a valid license. A person must be 18 years of
age or older to obtain a license. A person seeking a license shall apply on a form which
will be furnished by the AC Regional Director in the State in which that person operates
or intends to operate. The applicant shall provide the information requested on the
application form, including a valid mailing address through which the licensee or
applicant can be reached at all times, and a valid premises address where animals,
animal facilities, equipment, and records may be inspected for compliance. The
applicant shall file the completed application form with the AC Regional Director.

You failed to have a valid license prior to operating as an exhibitor of
regulated animals.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: August 8, 2015

15 U.S.C. § 1824(2) Unlawful Acts. The following conduct is prohibited: The (A)
showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition, of any horse which is sore,
(B) entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C) selling, auctioning or offering for sale, in any
horse sale or auction, any horse which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in
clause (A), (B), or (C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.”

9 C.F.R. § 11.3 Horses subject to this rule that do not meet the following scar rule
criteria shall be considered to be “sore” and are subject to all prohibitions of section 5 of
the Act.

You showed your horse “Sassy’s Slow Gen Fizz” (Entry #911, Class #17) at
the KWHA Mid-Summer Classic Horse Show in Stanford, KY while the
horse was sore and in violation of the scar rule.

aN VIOLATOR:
; oneal » Billy Howard
SOF Ben IG

VIOLATION OF FE AISREGULATIONS Eee (Streel, Cily, State, ZIP
2 \; a Ay Greensburg, KY 42743

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: August 8, 2015

15 U.S.C. § 1824(2) Unlawful Acts. The following conduct is prohibited: The (A)
showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition, of any horse which is sore,
(B) entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition, any horse which is sore. (C) selling, auctioning or offering for sale, in any
horse sale or auction, any horse which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in
clause (A), (B), or (C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.”

You entered your horse “Gens Major Knockout” (Entry #234, Class 6) for
the purpose of showing at the KWHA Mid-summer classic in Stanford, KY
while the horse was sore.

Reference Number: KY 160025-

## Enforcement Records-AWA and HPA-Sept to Oct 2016_page_562
USDA

Sa
ME unites states Department of Agriculture

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warming or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

APHIS OFFICIAL (Name): OFFICE ADDRESS:
Steven M. Bennett 4700 River Road, Unit 85
Riverdale, MD 20737

## Enforcement Records-AWA and HPA-Sept to Oct 2016_page_563
Animal and Plant Health
Inspection Service

Enforcement Services

Unit 85

Voice 301.851.2948

17-00922_000755

USDA

aa

VIA: USPS Certified Mail. Shipping: Ist October 20,
2016

Cathi Gruber
8605 Andrew Jackson Highway, SW
Cerro Gordo, NC 28430

OFFICIAL WARNING
Re: Reference number NC160020-AC
Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you violated the Horse Protection Act (15 U.S.C. § 1821 et seq.)
(HPA), as described in the attached Official Waming. Our agency, the Animal
and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing the
HPA, and other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and plant
pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may impose civil
penalties of up to $2,200, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Official Warning. Although we generally pursue penalties for this type of
violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this instance so long as

you comply, in the future. with laws that APHIS enforces.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you violate laws that APHIS
enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warming, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

What should I do if I have questions? If you have any questions concerning this
Official Warning, contact David Dissinger at (301) 851-2803 or call our main
office at (301) 851-2948.

Iam a small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding
APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?
If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health
laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small Business
Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you prefer to comment to someone outside
APHIS, contact the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsperson at
http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba.gov, or 1-888-REG-

FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s office receives comments and annually evaluates
federal agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs
of small businesses.

Sincerely,

Steven M. Bennett, Director
Investigative and Enforcement Services

UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE CASE NUMBER:
ANIMAL AND PLANT HEALTH INSPECTION SERVICE NC160020-AC
ai Ms VIOLATOR:
> Cathi Gruber
OFFIC

ADDRESS (Street, City, State, ZiP
Code):

Cerro Gordo, NC 28430

VIOLATION OF

L wan
) _

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: October 9, 2015
15 U.S.C. § 1824(2)(B) Unlawful acts - Entering

The following conduct is prohibited:

(2) The (A) showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition,
of any horse which is sore, (B) entering for the purpose of showing or
exhibiting in any horse show or horse exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C)
selling, auctioning, or offering for sale, in any horse sale or auction, any horse
which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in clause (A), (B), or
(C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.

Cathi Gruber was the owner and trainer who entered for the purpose of
showing, “Generator’s Santana’s Push” (class # 38, entry # 175) while sore, at
the North Carolina Championship Walking Horse Show in Fletcher, North
Carolina.

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

OFFICE ADDRESS:
4700 River Road, Unit 85
Riverdale, MD 20737

OFFICIAL WARNING
Re: Reference number NC160022-AC
Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you violated the Horse Protection Act (15 U.S.C. § 1821 et seq.)
(HPA), as described in the attached Official Waming. Our agency, the Animal
and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing the
HPA, and other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and plant
pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may impose civil
penalties of up to $2,200, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Official Warning. Although we generally pursue penalties for this type of
violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this instance so long as

you comply, in the future. with laws that APHIS enforces.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you violate laws that APHIS
enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warming, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

What should I do if I have questions? If you have any questions concerning this
Official Warning, contact David Dissinger at (301) 851-2803 or call our main
office at (301) 851-2948.

APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?
If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health
laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small Business
Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you prefer to comment to someone outside
APHIS, contact the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsperson at
http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba.gov, or 1-888-REG-

FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s office receives comments and annually evaluates
federal agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs
of small businesses.

Steven M. Bennett, Director

OFFICIAL WARNING
Re: Reference number NC160023-AC
Dear Sir or Madam:

We believe that you violated the Horse Protection Act (15 U.S.C. § 1821 et seq.)
(HPA), as described in the attached Official Waming. Our agency, the Animal
and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), is responsible for enforcing the
HPA, and other agriculture laws that help prevent the spread of animal and plant
pests and diseases, and ensure the welfare of animals.

After providing you with an opportunity for a hearing, we may impose civil
penalties of up to $2,200, or other sanctions, for each violation described in this
Official Warning. Although we generally pursue penalties for this type of
violation(s), we have decided not to pursue penalties in this instance so long as

you comply, in the future. with laws that APHIS enforces.

What happens if I do not comply in the future? If you violate laws that APHIS
enforces in the future, we may pursue criminal penalties, or we may pursue civil
penalties for the violations described in this Official Warming, in addition to any
penalties we may pursue for any future violations.

What should I do if I have questions? If you have any questions concerning this
Official Warning, contact David Dissinger at (301) 851-2803 or call our main
office at (301) 851-2948.

Iam a small business owner and have comments or concerns regarding
APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health laws. Who should I contact?
If you have comments about APHIS’s enforcement of animal and plant health
laws, please contact me, Steven M. Bennett, the APHIS Small Business
Ombudsperson, at (301) 851-2948. If you prefer to comment to someone outside
APHIS, contact the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsperson at
http://sba.gov/ombudsman, email ombudsman@sba.gov, or 1-888-REG-

FAIR. The Ombudsperson’s office receives comments and annually evaluates
federal agency enforcement activities for their responsiveness to the special needs
of small businesses.

Sincerely,

Steven M. Bennett, Director
Investigative and Enforcement Services
